reviewText:
This is a hard game to recomend but I am going to anyways. This game (at the time of my writing this) has many problems. But I think what the game does do well makes up for its problems. It might help if you go into the game with little to no expectations so that you are less dismayed by its faults. I will list some of the biggest problems I have with the game and then some of the main things I think make the game worth playing.

Problems:

1. Replacing older vehicles is a real chore. The need to keep up frequency on your lines really compounds this problem. Also there is no way to disable the annoying messages that fill the bottom of the screen notifying of a vehicle that has reached its life span.

2. I find the balancing of the stats on the vehicles along with when they come out and are made obsolete to be very poorly done. As one example the running costs of a locomotive is easily 10-20 times that of a road vehicle making the construction of train lines very risky if you don't know just the right circumstances to make a profitable line. And even if you can manage a profitable train line you are almost guarenteed to be able to make a much more profitable bus/tram or truck line in place of the train.

3. Collision issues while doing road and rail construction is very inflexible. It seems the majority of construction atempts are going to give you a collision message meaning it won't allow it. Often times you either have to make significant compromises to your plans, forget your plans altogether, or invest a lot of money and work into making it work. Such as spending millions of dollars bulldozing buildings along a road just so you can upgrade the road or connect another road to the road, even if there was a large open spot where no buildings were in the way.

Good things:

1. The sounds and visuals of the game are very appealing in my opinion. I spend much of my time just following vehicles around or watching people go whereever they are going. I think the next closest game of this type would be Cities in Motion but sunnier.

2. The randomly generated maps and cities are very impressive. Granted there isn't a lot of variety in the generation catogories for the maps, but even so, the type of landscape it does generate is very well done. As far as I know there is no other game of this type that has comparable map and city generation. Also the way the cities gradually develope is well done and satisfying. The speed at which they grow is largely based on how well connected the town is with itself and with other towns as well as how fully it is being supplied with goods.

3. The realistic supply and demand of the passengers in the game is really nice and gives a lot of incentive to connect to every town you can. Every person has 4 locations they are assigned. A home, a place of work, a place to shop and a place for leisure. They will often re-assign locations based on what new options are available. They have a 20 minute deadline on any travel plans they make. So the faster your transportation becomes the further they can travel within the time limit and so the more opertunities exist for you to make money in transporting them.

These are just some of the more prominant issues, both good and bad, that exist in the game. But it hopefully gives a sense of whether you might enjoy the game or not. The balancing problem I mention can relatively easily be dealt with through mods. Finding the right one for your tastes and installing them is a bit of a hassle though when ideally the game could have just been better balanced by the developers themselves.

I personnally think it is a great game and have had a lot of enjoyment with it. But the lost potential of what this game could be is admittedly frustrating and I can certainly understand why some people might be too put off to continue playing it.

reviewText:
Don't get me wrong. Train Fever is not a perfect game. There are some performance issues on larger maps, some aspects of micromanaging are tedious, and I question the balance between train and truck income.

That said, it's still a pretty decent game in a genre that doesn't get alot of love. And if you enjoy building train lines and roads and such, there's a good chance you'll find something to like in Train Fever.

I really like the UI, which is really important in this kind of game. It's simple, unintrusive, and fully customizable. You can follow any number of vehicles, lines, charts, etc. I also like how when you have a window open, like of a vehicle, you can zoom within the window, click on a building within the window, and that will open a new window.

The building and terraforming tools are quite good once you have them fully figured out. Graphics could be better, but they don't distract from the experience. Good music.

Even with its flaws, I can still recommend this game. If you have any fond memories of the transport sims of yesteryear, Train Fever is worth a play.

reviewText: Currently it's hard to recommend this game. While I have been having some fun with it, it also has some very irritating bugs and shortcomings. It's not always easy to get tracks right, you have to build it in short sections, and there is no way to design a track without actually paying for it. I've lost millions of in-game money by placing a track, only to find out at the last moment that something is unable to align.\n\nI finally did manage to get a map working and see some nice action, only to notice the game performance collapsing in on itself. We've been discussing this issue a lot on the official forums, but until the developers fix it, i can't really give this game a recommendation to anyone else. When you got a lot of track on a big map and a lot of vehicles, the frame rate simply tumbles and at the end of every in-game month, while the game does some calculations, it will simply freeze for up to 30s. Enjoyable for shorter sessions, but in the long run the issues take the fun out of it.

reviewText: Wonderful game! Its fine as vanilla, and even better with mods. It's like having your own living model railroad, without spending a fortune. As the game goes on, the towns grow toward your stations, buildings, cars, and even the pedestrian's clothing styles change. You can spend hours just getting your lines set perfectly; the learning curve is not too steep, yet the gameplay is pretty complex, with each individual citizen having their own schedule, home, and workplace.\n\nAll that complexity has a bit of a price though; I don't recommend playing a map size larger than small" if you have a 32 bit system. Even with 64 bits

reviewText:
Definetely a big recommend!

The game is missing a big tutorial, it just starts with basic tutorials how to set up your first transportation line with automatically moving vehicles. However, it's all about transportation and getting money for it. So there is not much more you have to use, except your human logic.

So your transportation lines have to make sense. At first you have to check WHAT should be transported. For beginners, use trains and check out two companies that are close to each other.

Company 1: Produces oil and sells it on the market
Company 2: Needs oil in order to produce goods

So, as you can imagine, in real life Company 1 would love to sell it's oil to Company 2 who absolutely needs it. BID AND ASK. All right, so just build two railway stations next to these companies, connect them. Create a new line in between these two railway stations, buy a train, tell it to drive according to the line you just created and thats it.

The companies will notice AUTOMATICALLY that there NOW is a possibility to sell/buy oil from each other. The AI in this came is intelligent enough to notice this advantage. So Company 1 now notices, that there is a way to transport and sell it's oil to Company 2 using your railway station. What does Company 1 do now? It starts stacking up the produced oil barrels on your railway station. Your train will arrive, pick up the barrels, drive to Company 2 who automatically buys it. After arriving at Company 2 you instantly get the money. That's pretty simple.

Now, for example, Company 2 takes Oil and produces GOODS. Villages and people living there need the goods. So what you can create a second transportation line between a nearby village and Company 2, in order to transport the produces goods to the village. Similar as in the example above, the companies/villages will notice this advantage and start ordering goods from Company 2 using your second line. Again you're earning money.

Now, as the village gets goods to develop, you can also start building a THIRD line. On the lower right side of the user interface you can open a menu. One of the points allows you to show the houses of villages in colored codes. After enabling this option, you will see blue, yellow and green houses.

Green houses = Houses where people live in
Yellow houses = Stores and places for people to have fun (e.g. after work)
Blue houses = Offices/workplaces for the people that work

If you zoom in you can see that people have to walk a LOT from their homes in order to go to work every morning. So what you can do is simply creating a THIRD line to allow the people to travel from home to work by bus. Again the AI is intelligent enough to notice this advantage, so they will immediately start using your busses and pay money for tickets.

Then, after more and more people work, your city gets more efficient. Companies grow and develop thanks to your lines transportating the workers, so after growing even MORE people can work there. Also the houses where families life in. The better the lines are set up, the more attractive the area in your city gets, leading to a rising population in your city. You really can see the city growing over time.

So a last example, after work the people may be exhausted, so they need to relax, maybe going to yellow houses and playgrounds in the city. so why don't create a fourth line that transports the people in between work/stores/their home? They will use it then again.

All you have to do in this game is thinking logically. The world is amazingly intelligent, it is fun to watch the city growing. Even companies grow if they notice that they can't produce enough products anymore in order to supply other companies. Every single move and line you create, every single bus stop, can change the peoples behavior and influence the way your city grows. This is fantastic.

reviewText:
I play this game since Beta and it is getting better and better. The developers listen to the community and already implemented a lot of wishes. If you played OTTD you should know, that this game is different in some aspects:

- The industry chains are smaller but production does not increase/decrease at random and it matters where you deliver the goods because cities will only accept a certain amount.
- The scale of the game is different, you won't have a station with 10 tracks in each town in this game unless you are crazy.  It is not like OTTD where you build 20 trains for one line, it focusses more on longer lines between cities. That said, you will most likely have less networks and less complex setups for station entrances and rail crossings because it is not so easy to build such things.
- The terrain in this game really matters. In OTTD you can just terraform everything at some point and tracks can just go up the hill anywhere. Here it matters where you lay your tracks and you have to plan according to the contour lines.

If you can live with that, you get a really good game with:

- Great graphics
- Already great mods (see trainfever.net)
- Simulated people and goods
- Simulated town growth
- Great maps

So what issues do I have with the game:
- If you build a lot of stuff, it takes time to autosave and sometimes the simulation slows down
- Balancing of some trains and cars needs some work, TFV for example won't reach 300 km/h on most tracks because of weak acceleration (they changed the TFV but I couldn't test it since the changes)
- Trains sometimes drive one after another because of long boarding times. This affects profit and line frequency (this has now been fixed)

-------------------------

Addition now that the US DLC is out:

Some of my concerns have been adressed:
- Performance of the game is better, still a slight slowdown when autosave (but you can now choose how often the autosave is done)
- Balancing is still not perfect but TFV is fixed
- Boarding times are less of an issue


The US DLC works fine, I didn't see all the models yet. But there even seem to be options to enable all vehicles (Europe and US) and just play on a Europe or US map, which is great. I don't know if the balancing of the US vehicles is good because I am still in 1870.
There are still some old bugs in the game but nothing game-breaking, mostly visual little annoying things like missing tunnel portals.

I tested some mods and there are awesome vehicles available. Unfortunately the old mods are broken but there is already a solution out (the community has a mod manager which will do all the work for you). If you do some research it is easy to find new vehicles or balance mods and add them to the game. With the new ingame tools you should then be able to really customize your experience, which is great!

reviewText:
After 150 hours of playing time I must admit that I deeply love this game.It is amazing that it took so long for a new game in the railroad transportation genre to appear after all the successes with Transport Tycoon, Locomotion, Cities in Motion, or even 3DTT / Schiene und Strasse. With Train Fever today we finaly do have a worthy successor!

I had the fortunate opportunity to be one of the beta testers of Train Fever,so I may have seen a big portion of the progress this game took from the first more or less playable version up until the release. I am happy that all important points and rough edges that I pointed out during the beta were OK in the end when the game was released. But the guys from Urban Games did not stop there, they did from release and still keep continuing development to make the game even better. Until this very day there have been maybe 5 to 10 patches after the release, each adding much sought after updates to the game engine, added features, new rolling stock, and improved usability.

This leads me to say that the game is now in a very polished, playable and truly enjoyable state.Honestly, I would not have said so at the release, I think the game was released a bit too early for its state. But now, after all those fixes, There is not a single point left of those that kept me frustrating in the beginning. From my personal experience, I think it's very rare to see such a progress, as today most games are released and then abandoned by the studio, as they are mostly working on the next game already. But Urban games did not go this shady path.

The fact that Train Fever was designed with deep mod support in mindfrom the first day of development makes the game even more exciting for me. There are a couple of mods that I really enjoy playing with. Most of them are additions to rolling stock, but for example there is also one that installs a much more complicated and challenging industry chain. In case you are german speaking, don't forget to look at one of the largest community portals of the game: http://www.train-fever.net/

All this together with the quite low price they are selling Train Fever on Steamlead to my final conclusion: It really is a game worth playing. If you're into the genre I think it's an absolute must to own it! But even if you're new to the field or not so much into trains, trucks and transportation, I still think the beauty and realism with which Train Fever presents itself is worth to give it a try.

If that does not hold you off buying this fancy masterpiece, you should go ahead and get it (They need your financial help developing).

reviewText:
Train Fever is a game I enjoy but needs more work. I followed this game for a while before release and Urban Games seems pretty committed to making this a good game so I have confidence in them.

So let's get the basics out of the way. On the one hand it's a pretty straight forward game. If you've played Cities in Motion or Tranportation Tycoon you won't be lost. The game looks pretty good even on my old computer and considering I'm using Vista it runs pretty smoothly.

One of the first problems and it may seem like a small one is that you can't make tracks that crossover each other. You can make switches or bridges, but if I have two tracks (an up and down line) and I want it to cross over and merge with another set of tracks I can't do that. I have to make an additional set of switches. I imagine that will be implimented eventually but it really annoys me because from how I play in games like OpenTTD I usually have one or two main lines with branch lines feeding it.

Another small thing that gets really annoying fast is that you can't build roads over track (unless you build a bridge). Again this will be a quick fix, but it will really started to make me mad when I was trying to upgrade my old lines to high speed tracks.

One thing is that trains are supposed to dynamically spread themselves out they don't stack up on each other, but it seems it has somes bugs. At first it worked fine, but as I got into the late game the system seems to break down so I'd always have three or more trains at one end of a three station line and the other had nothing. I actually watched this for a little bit to figure out why and I think what happens is that when you get into the late game and have trains with a 100+ passengers that it creates  bottleneck with all those people loading and unloading.

I'm not convinced that cargo is really flushed out. I struggle to make cargo lines to make any kind of profit and really by the 20th century it's better to use trucks.

I think the building of roads and tracks needs work. Sometimes it's a crapshoot on what will work and what doesn't.

Still these all strike me as problems that are easy to fix and probably the devs are on it already. Train Fever seems like a pretty solid base to expand upon and Urban Games seems to have big plans and if an active modding community can get off the ground I see great things for the game. This game is really for people who really love transport tycoon games.

reviewText:
This game always felt like a very expensive Beta.   And it is. It's a 40 dollar beta.  It is unsettling knowing that the devs can essentially take the money and run at any point.   Though, they've stuck with it so far.

So...why shouldn't you get this game?

As stated, it's simply not finished.   This is hearlding to be the next Transport Tycoon/Locomotion.   And it's just not that.   Want to electrify all your rails?   Click every individual section,  miss one and your train wont run.  Don't know what section you missed?  Good luck finding it.

Want to built a road across your rails?  Too bad.  Demolish the rails and build the road first,  then you can fiddle around.

The building system is beyond fickle,  though in honesty,  it has been improving.   It's still awful.   You will spend more time cursing it out and trying to get a simple little bit just to work.  It needs a lot of work

Natrually,  there is no true build mode,   so any minor change that doesn't work will be bulldozed out of your own poked, paid to be laid again, and bulldozed when that doesn't work.  Early on, if you make even a slight error building your track,  you can break the bank.

Likewise,  making a profit is not very difficult...but it's also not very intuitive.

Industry chains are short and pathetic.  They are rarely profitable, unless you manage to hook up differnt industries on one line,  and you're better off using Trucks most the time.

Oddly enough, Intercity busses are perferred later in game over trains as well.   With roads being much easier to manipulate and control,  trains really just become a novelty.

There is water in game,  however it serves no purpose other than to build bridges that don't like being built.   It's a shame because the water actually looks lovely,  and forms into huge lakes, rivers and streams.   It just begs for water transit.  The starting year is 1850,  Paddle driven ships were in full swing,  and hadn't fully replaced sail yet.

Maps are more than large enough. So yes, this is a positive.  They can be downrigt massive.  Archipeligo, and more water based maps would be completely doable.  Along the lines of huge maps,  unlike in Transit Tycoon, or Locomotion,  these are actually big enoug that airplanes would really make sense.    Unfortunatly, there are no airplanes.

Optimization is ok.  It chugs later on as cities grow.  But this too has been improving.  It also still needs work,

Variation is low.      It's a solid start of mechanics...but there needs to be a lot of refinement,  a lot of additional content,  and ♥♥♥, I dont' even care if ships, aircraft, are additional cost DLC,  that's fine. I understand these people need money to make their game,  but 40 USD is simply too much for such an incomplete game.

EDIT
You will have fun with this game.  It is pretty,  trains do run once you -eventually- get the tracks down.  Profits can be had, the whole 9 yards.  You won't,  however,  have 40 dollars worth of fun with it.   It seems that not hours after this review went up,  the devs announced a North American DLC.   So,  variation in theory should be helped,  but the flaws of construction,  limited industry,  water transit, and aircraft still remain.
END EDIT

EDIT 2 - USA DLC released-
Okay so we now have the American DLC.   It was free so if you haven't bought this game yet,   well, still don't buy it.   It doesn't really Fix" any of the issues. If anything it makes the game much harder in the early era due to how the US stuff is balanced.  You still can't do basic things like buiding a rail road crossing with a road. (you have to built it with a rails overtop of roads)

reviewText:
I really good game and the best alternative to the obsolete Transport Tycoon series. Really lovely 3D graphic and alot of possibilities to add content via DLC or modding.
However I think some work should be done still :

1. Add the possibility to load a previous game directly from the current one without exiting to the main menu.
2. Add the possibility to delete old save games.
3. Give more starting money or lower the cost of vehicles.
4. Make industries and cities start to give passengers or good immediately without waiting too long.
5. Make the maps bigger with more cities and more industries.
6. Add real world areas and sceniaros.
7. Improve the construction of the railroad making it a bit easier since the leveling is a real pain.
8. Add the possibility to improve the stations without destroing the previous one.
9. Make more variety of stations and make possible to combine passenger and cargo in one station.
10. Add better more real accurate depots for trains
11. Some more will add later.

In the end a good product which has alot of potential and the above points should be addressed asap.

reviewText:
This game gave away all its potential and i'm sorry to say that, sucks in the long term.
The key feature of the game - building tracks - is annoying and doesnt work properly like hell. If it works the way it should, it's totally hard to handle and not a useful tool. Given the fact, the devs advertised the game by pointing out the building tool, this is even more annoying.

See, the trains ingame can't climb or decend steep slopes, which is perfectly allright, since this is the same in RL. This is why tracks often are build on a dam or an expensive tunnel is build. The thing ingame is that the building AI doesnt always build cost effective or with common sense. So you start building in small parts of the track just to find out, when coming to the end of the planned track (e.g. another station) you cannot connect it. Sometimes it's not even because of the terrain but because of nonsense like can't build a bridge, cant put a switch here and so on. It's so frustrating.

There are various other reasons why the game is no fun, such as a very simple and monotone economy but the track building tool, which was highly advertised by the devs is the worst.

I feel i'm playing an early access game. Other studios certainly wouldn't have sold that as a final.

Hope this helped, deleting the game from my lib now.

As well as better dynamic city generation and trams added.

Wonderful attention to detail in the 3D models, basically you can sit hours and watch the trains chug along the countrysides.


It is still a bit rough here and there but I don't have any doubts the dedicated devs will resolve these problems quickly.

reviewText:
I think it's a good game.

You can build passenger and cargo lines (with trains, bus, streetcars, trucks...) and connect the towns and industries to each other, which is fun.  The simulation is very solid. Every inhabitant has a persistent home, work, a recreational area and a preferred shop where he or she likes to go. Cities grow when they are connected to other cities via your transportation network or get goods delivered.

The optical presentation is nice which makes it very satisfying to watch the networks come to life. The cities are very lovely done, except sometimes the surrounding lands feels a little bit monotonous. There aren't any premade maps, instead they are procedural generated.

There are some rough edges at the moment, some are mentioning a bad performance. I had this problem at first, too. But simply lowering the graphic settings helped a lot.

The biggest oversight in my opinion is that the developers somehow missed to provide a user guide and the tutorial is lacking. It doesn't explain all important things. Some people are simply lost and rely on user generated guides or youtube videos at the moment, which understandably frustrates them. So if you plan to play Train Fever I like to advise you to look at some guides and videos first. (Here is a very good interactive guide.[trainfeverguide.26miledrive.com])

For instance there are things that work differently than in other transportation simulations or aren't very obvious: Stops don't have a coverage area, instead people are trying to reach their destination in under 20 minutes. For instance this can mean they are willing to walk 17 minutes to a bus stop, use the bus for 2 minutes and walk another minute (of course it's better the closer stops are). They won't use a transportation network if travel times are longer than 20 minutes or if they can reach it on their own faster (by foot or car).
With freight it's similar. It's not possible to order freight, own can only provide lines and the  business owner" decides whether to use your trains and trucks
date:
to deliver freight on his own or to not produce at all. It needs to be delivered in under 20 minutes and the frequency and capacity of your vehicles determines how much will be delivered using your transportation network.


What really stands out is the ability to mod the game
recommended: which will contribute immensely to the longevity of it. There are already mods available that add more vehicles or more industries and goods."

reviewText:
Allright, the game came out this morning and i've literally been playing non stop.

As a BIG fan of tycoon games, especially Chris Sawyer's TTD and the open source version, Words simply cannot describe my anticipation for this game.


Train Fever is everything any tycoon fan could want, a game that feels like it was made by a A+ developer, funded by one of the big giants, but it's all made by a small indie studio, which makes it even more incredible than it already is. the tycoon genre has long had games that were good, but not great, and far, far too many games that were bad. But train fever stands out, it is truly an amazing game.

The music is fantastic.
It is tricky to learn and you don't easily get to a point where you are insanely rich and nothing stops you
The graphics, while they can be laggy at times, are stunning to look at. With good sound effects to follow, watching the trains moving along, while listening to the soundtrack is just great.
Laying tracks is easy, but it can be tricky. However, like other parts of this game, once you learn it, you souldn't have problems.
The game might not have a million features, and at times the wait untill you get a new train is long, but it's enjoyable. That's what is important, i really, really like this game. It isn't perfect, it's still a little rough around the edges, but i havn't had a single crash (although i encountered a few bugs).

Overall, i can easily recommend this to any tycoon fan.
In fact, if you are a tycoon fan, you simply must buy it.

SHIRO-A RECOMMENDS THIS GAME!
10/10!

reviewText:
I have to say, this is a great tycoon game (It is not a simulation), because of the sounds of the locomotives, music is good to listen to.

This game isn't too distant from another game I enjoy, called Open TTD, but there are stuff I'd like to mention that I'd like which are:

Grid less terrain is a welcome change to what I'm used to. The 3D aspect of it makes you have to carefully choose where to put the lines, it also makes track and road laying realistic, including gradients.

Contour lines makes it easier to dictate slope steepness and greatly assist in designing a railway.

The procedural towns and cities are a welcome sight as it makes them fully dynamic

There are a couple of bad points that I'd like to mention though:

The game needs a great deal of polishing and optimisation as it runs poorly on my PC

Constructing railways I find, is difficult, you can't exactly plan the entire line in one go.

reviewText:
I've played this for nearly 24 hours.  I wanted to give it a good play before reviewing.  Let's just say I've had a lot of fun with this, to a disturbingly addictive level.

Stuff I like:

+ Nice big maps.  Bright colours but it adds to the charm
+ Cities Grow
+ You can watch a single person go to work and back on your network.
+ Once you pull off a complicated track arrangement it is incredibly satisfying.
+ The way cargo works makes sense to me.  You can't just deliver coal to a factory and presume you'll make money.  The factory has to have it's goods going somewhere too.
+ You find all kinds or nice looking views and moments when touring your network, a track wrapping around a hill, or a large train emptying dozens of people at a station where a bus is waiting.

There is a somewhat steep learning curve at the beginning, mainly because there is barely any manual and only a brief tutorial.  There are plenty of steam guides though so make sure you read them before playing.  A little tip for those just starting: Build your railway lines in smaller chunks, and avoid going directly up a hill.

There are a bunch of weird little bugs, for example, you can build tracks over roads but not roads over tracks, which you have to work around, but it seems the developer is still working on things, and there are bug fixes on the way apparently.

If you are coming from Transport Tycoon to this, be aware it doesn't do everything the same, in particular, trains only use one assigned platform at a station (devs also working on this).

If you are thinking of buying this, don't be fooled into thinking this is not an intensive game on your system.  Double check your system specs before buying.

Also, this game is mod friendly and there are already fan made mods available, including a largely expanded cargo network.

reviewText:
I see a number of people saying this doesn't work on an iMac. Well I bought it today (Sunday 21 Sep 14) and it installed and worked perfectly. In case anyone missed it, this title requires that permissions be granted via the System Prefs. On Mavericks go to Security & Privacy and then choose Accessability. Click the padlock in the lower left corner of the window and type in your admin password. That should case the options to becaome available. Scroll the list of apps down until you find Steam and activate the check box next to it. Close the window and restart Steam. You should now be able to get Train Fever to work. It does also appear to be a 64bit app if that makes any difference to anyone with issues around getting it to work.

The game itself is pretty good. Ifound the thing a bit jumpy when zooming the map out until I adjusted the Shadows option to low. Having said that I also noted that it was a function of detail that cased the stuttering and that all the time you work at realtively close quarters to the ground you can actually have everything set to high including the Shadows option.

It seems fairly straightforward to operate and I recognised a lot of how it worked from having played Railway Tycoon in my shady past. Would I reccomend it? Yes I think I would.

I can see that anyone looking for a  detailed rail sim with mega amounts of choices on a Mac would probably be happier with Trains, but having said that I still think you would probably find this plenty enjoyable too. All in all a good buy.

Hope this helps some of you having troubles with this title out there in Steam land.

reviewText:
Train Fever is an entertaining game, with a few flaws, but an overall enjoyable expierence.

In Train Fever you run a transprort company from the 19th to the 21st century, using buses, trams, and trains to make a profit shipping people and cargo. I liked how the game started in 1850 as comparable games such as Transport Tycoon, and Cities in Motion start way later, which certainly changes your stradegy in the early game. The simulation is easy to understand yet difficult to master. The Graphics are quite pleasing to the eye, and the soundtrack is pretty catchy compared to other sim games I have played. The game is challenging and there are many stradegies to try to make a profit. The Randomly generated maps are a great addition that diffinatly add replay value. ISometimes it is simply great to watch your trains race around the landscape. Basically this game is what Transport Tycoon could have been if it was made today in 3D.

However the game does have some issues. Track laying is very difficult. Rather than clinging to the landscape like you would expect it to, it is completely independant of it, meaning you will have a lot tracks raised and lowered around the ground. It is also finickey and will often give errors when it is clear there should not be one. The UI is not exactly Intuitive either. However it seems the devoloper is apt to fix these problems.

Overall I would recomend this game to any fan of Railroad Tycoon, Cities in Motion and especially Transport Tycoon, as it is a complex quality expierence.

reviewText:
If you are a transport sim fan and you can't put up with the graphics of '90's legendary games any more, this is your game. It may need some more work to match the legends in terms of gameplay, but the platform is very promising. The company behind it seems to be keen in improving it and they also seem to be encouraging modders to contribute content.

Pros:
good large random maps
decent 3D graphics
dynamic cities expansion
good passenger simulation
and most importantly, it's the only trasport sim of our day (to my knowledge at least) supporting passenger+freight. Hence, our only hope.
Cons:
freight aspect needs some help
could be smoother performance-wise
UI could be prettier and easier to use
a campaign mode would make it more attractive for non-hardcore trasportation sim fans
To sum it up, if you are a fan of the genre, you need to check this out eventually. I wouldn't blame you if decide to wait a couple of updates first though.

reviewText:
This review of mine is based on the latest version (build 5798).

Train fever is unique in its gameplay. Each and every passenger and goods in the game have their own choice regarding their destination. Their choice is not fixed but depends upon your transport  network. Better a route, more chances of people travelling in that route.  They also may change vehicles in between their destinations.

Its basically a Sandbox game and you are free to chose how you transport people (or goods). For example you might want to create 2 railway station in 2 cities to transport people. Alternatively you can build a railway station on outskirts and then transport people from various part of the city to the railway station from which they will be travel by train to another train station. Its all up to you. This freeform of gameplay is really addictive.
Graphically the game looks awesome. Animations are superb and sound is quite nice. Specially the train sounds.
The game also supports MODS, which means lots of user made suff is available

SINCE ITS RELEASE THE GAME HAS IMPROVED in terms of performance and user interface.

However the downside of this games are:
It still has performance issues specially on large maps
User interface has issues
There are very few industries in the game. However few mods are already availabe that increase varaiety.

reviewText:
This game is an intelligent and modern implementation of the railroad tycoon genre. I love it! The small development team has put a lot of work and love into details and created an impressing simulation that is also beautiful (except the user interface).

- Procedural generation of large landscapes and growth of cities is stunningly implemented and very intelligent - this helps to creates unique cities and worlds with different challenges.
- Track-laying is very realistic (wow, really what I was dreaming for in RRT 3 etc with costs depending on degree of terrain modification).
- Beautiful graphics of engines (buses) and towns.
- Challenging simulation - neat combination of in-city and intra-city transportation of passengers.
- Nice timeline with great European locomotives.

The focus is really on moving people around which is really enjoyable and the fun challenge to keep the economy running - I wish developers would not have listened to the community and rather would have entirely omitted the freight side of the game (to sell this feature separately later as a DLC!).

I also find that the game's procedural world could have benefited from more variation, both geographically and temporally - there are no seasonal effects, and independent on height, the terrain texture is boring green lawn. I think they could have done much by simply changing textures with height (from green pastures to alpine rock desert) and over the course of a year (vegetation and texture change) - just to make epic playing over hours more immersive and entertaining.

Overall I recommend this game - finally an intelligent, modern implementation of the classic genre after all the Sim City disasters (Cities in Motion being an exception).

reviewText:
Train Fever is rough around the edges but there’s a solid foundation there that just needs a bit of refinement. This is a game that could have benefited from an Early Access period though not necessarily a very long one.

The foundation of any transport game is the cargo modelling. If you’ve played Transport Tycoon there’ll be an adjustment period as in Train Fever industries “order” goods rather than accept them. In Transport Tycoon you can happily take iron ore to a steel mill all day long and make a tidy profit. In Train Fever that iron ore will only appear if there is a demand for it – the steel mill has to see demand for its end product in order to want to pay for iron ore and coal. No demand means no cargo to transport. Instead of setting up a transport route, you have to set up the entire chain. It’s an interesting mechanic but unfortunately it’s a bit finicky and it can be hard to figure out why an industry is not producing anything after the millions you have invested in a shiny transport network.

Passenger transportation works differently too, as individual people and their journeys are simulated. People will walk from their residences to their destination if no transport route exists. If your service comes to their stop often enough (represented as Frequency in the game) then they may choose to ride your buses and trains. Conversely, if they can get there quicker by walking then they’ll do that. That means that whenever you set up a new route there is a higher expense because you have to supply enough vehicles so that the Frequency on the route is low enough for people to take it – another adjustment for those of us used to building a line with a single train set to full load and then letting it do its thing.

Construction is seamless and mostly intuitive, which is lucky because the tutorial in the game isn’t particularly fleshed out. You can drag out new sections of road or rail, and rail will show you the maximum speed trains will be able to reach on the new section (based on gradient and the radius of the curve). You can tweak the height of the endpoint and drag it around to a new location until you’re happy and then confirm the construction. Unfortunately tracks can only cross each other without a bridge, which makes diverging routes harder to build than they should be once you have double track covering the map. The game will give you a message if you can’t build track in the way you want, but on occasion there’ll be no explanation, just no “confirm” box. This tends to be only a small annoyance, and most of the time building new tracks is enjoyable.

Outside of the construction interface the user interface has a clean look. The highlight is the line manager where you can also manage your vehicles, easily sending all vehicles assigned to a line to their nearest depot and even having them automatically sold when it’s time to replace them. It can get a little unwieldy as you start managing more lines but the devs have thought of this with a “visible only” feature which filters out lines not currently on the screen. Depots make it very easy to buy vehicles and then add them all to the same line. There doesn’t appear to be a way to resize windows and the font can be hard to read sometimes – a UI scaling feature would be nice. A word of warning: the game seemingly has no keyboard shortcuts at all and so relies entirely on the mouse which can be fatiguing.

Line management is intuitive as well – create a line, hit “add station” and click away on the stations in order. The game will calculate a path for vehicles to take, and vehicles will automatically space themselves out along the route. The more vehicles (or the faster the vehicles), the higher the frequency. Pathing works very well for road vehicles, but with trains it’s another matter. Currently train lines choose a specific platform to use at a station, and trains will usually wait until that platform is free before pulling in, even if your station has other empty platforms they could use. I’ve even had a train sit waiting for the specific platform so long that the next train on the line was queued behind it; the second train picked the empty platform instead with seemingly no rhyme or reason. I’ve started building platforms based on the number of lines that will be serving the station as opposed to the number of trains I expect to service the line, which is annoying.

The game’s graphics are great as can be seen in the screenshots and videos and sounds are good throughout. Admiral James T. has done an incredible job with the soundtrack, with tracks which sound like tributes to themes from Transport Tycoon and even one which may be a nod to Theme Hospital. After about 9 hours of play I’m still enjoying the music and smiling when I recognise one of the tribute songs.

Even with the rough edges however I’d recommend this game to anyone who enjoys transport simulations or trains. You’ll have to take some time to figure out the new mechanics and on occasion you will be frustrated by the mostly minor issues. If you can move on from those there is an enjoyable game here.

This review was written after playing Build 4221.

reviewText:
This game *is* Transport Tycoon but without a grid, and with prettier graphics. If you've never played Transport Tycoon, then this game is probably not for you.

The good part about this game is - it's Transport Tycoon! You get to build road and rail, and buses, trains and whatnot. You start in the horse-and-carriage era and work your way up. Map and towns are generated and driven by supply and demand and it is up to you to decide what that means! For anyone who played the original TT, this is a blast. The depots, the newspapers, the lines! The game even includes our beloved train signals, which means that you can also compete with yourself in getting as close as you can 100% track utilization!

The bad part about this game is - it's Transport Tycoon. Transport Tycoon was relased in '95 and that means that we have gotten quite far since. When playing this game, it really hits you how things have changed. The general UI design is: 1) Open a window for everything, and 2) Provide very few hints. Want to know the coverage area of a bus stop? Well, you can't. Want to replace your fleet of 100+ vehicles with an identical replacement once they reach a certain age? Well, you can't. Want to understand why the iron ore mine that has a production capacity of 25 only outputs 1 item a year? Well, too bad, but you can't.

Furthermore, the game is a sandbox, offering no AI enemies and no multiplayer. While everything is freshly generated every time you start a new game, I'd probably say it's repeatable rather than replayable.

The steam community is right in giving this a 'Mixed' grade right now. Me, I am going to go ahead and click recommend, because it's Tranport Tycoon, you know?

reviewText:
This is a good, highly addictive game inspired by similar games in the genre.
Personally, I love it, even with the poor performance I am seeing late game, I still can't get enough.
The dev's seem passionate about it and are pumping our regular patches / updates, which is refreshing.

Pro's
+Dev's seem to care about the game and are patching / looking to add new things
+Large Seeded Maps
+Proceduraly generated city growth
+Fairly straight forward to get to grips with, although worthwhile checking out user created guides.
+Good graphics
+Moddable, there are lots of mods available to DL, inc vehicles / new industry chains etc.

Con's
-Performance issues (being worked on)
-UI could do with some polish / tweak's
-Lack of in-game tutorial (but user guides cover this imho and its not that complex)
-Replacing Vehicles due to old age can become a chore
-Lack of some track options, such as crossovers |X| although you can do single line crossings |/|

Things to look out for:
- Ensure you have a graphics card capable of OpenGL 3.2

reviewText:
UPDATED REVIEW!!!!!

I have almost 1000 hours of play time so I will now take the time to edit my review....

If I had waited a week after launch before buying this game, I probably would not have purchased. All the beta tester reviews were positive but this game still needs a lot of work. As far as I'm concerned its still in beta.

*edit* The above is still somewhat true and let me add that I get the vibe that the game developers are relying too much on user created/mods to make the game complete.


My biggest gripes with the game:

1. Cargo trains don't make any money but cargo trucks do.
*edit* Making money with cargo trains takes time but can be lucrative.

2. Track laying can sometimes be a pain in the neck.
*edit* This was understated; it really is a pain!

3. The game needs some sort of manual to better explain things. Most of the help and guides I have seen are done by people whose first language wasn't English.
4. Don't get me started on signals. I still do not fully understand how they really work so I haven't been using them, hence the need for a manual.
*edit* Okay, I understand signals now but I still think the game needs a manual.

5. The biggest gripe I have is that McAfee detects one of the Train Fever files as a virus and quarrantines it. Eveytime I want to play I have disable real time scanning and have Steam re-verify the file. I don't like the idea of having my computer vulnerable but I'm willing to risk it. When I'm done playing I'll turn real time scanning back on and once again it will detect the file as a virus and remove it. then I have to go through all the above steps again.
*edit* This was fixed a while ago so no longer applies.

I mean the game is fun, but you have patience and stick with it.  I don't want to not recommend the game but it doesn't seem right to recommend it (at this time) either.

*edit* I hear a lot of people comparing this to OTTD. I never played that or the original but I have played RRT2, Sid Meier's Railroads, and Locomotion. This game can be better than all of them but still hasn't lived up to its potential.

reviewText:
I just started playing this game and it looks like it's going to be much fun. As promised, it's like Transport Tycoon, 20 years later :) Graphics is very good, cities, roads and railroads look much better than they did in TT, and you can actually build them in any direction you want.

However, it has some problems. Gameplay isn't very intuitive (TT was much better in this area) and tutorials do not help much. GUI is not easy to use (too much menus and windows, not enough direct controls on the map - you have to click 20 times to set up a train line, it should be much quicker and easier).

I hope devs will fix those problems and make the learning curve less steep, because this looks just great and I'm sure I'm going to have lots of fun playing this game.

And, what's more remarkable, I haven't seen any bugs or crashes. It looks like a pretty smooth release.

reviewText:
I just started playing this game and it looks like it's going to be much fun. As promised, it's like Transport Tycoon, 20 years later :) Graphics is very good, cities, roads and railroads look much better than they did in TT, and you can actually build them in any direction you want.

However, it has some problems. Gameplay isn't very intuitive (TT was much better in this area) and tutorials do not help much. GUI is not easy to use (too much menus and windows, not enough direct controls on the map - you have to click 20 times to set up a train line, it should be much quicker and easier).

I hope devs will fix those problems and make the learning curve less steep, because this looks just great and I'm sure I'm going to have lots of fun playing this game.

And, what's more remarkable, I haven't seen any bugs or crashes. It looks like a pretty smooth release.

reviewText:
This game has alot of potential but can be alittle spazy when loading into maps. compaired to most simulation tycoon games this one has its own way of working. Unlike most transportation based games you cant force it to do what you want. Each enity (person and cargo) has a place it wants to go and you cant always force the entity to go where you want it to go, you need to work with the entity to speed ups its movement

There is already a few good mods showing up it is sure to be a good that will keep improving both with its own way of working and with the comunities help

Pathing for trains and vehicles can also be a bit spazy and will sometimes forget where it should go but if you have your signaling right you will have very little issues.

With the map you wont be able to jump right in, when you load into the map you will need yo pan around to load the map completly otherwise you will lock up and load slowly by doing that you will be able to run your game with very little hickups with loading.

reviewText:
I now spent a nice amount of time with the game so I can voice my opinion about it.
In many ways it is exactly what I needed, although it could sure use some improvements down the road.
Good:
- Nice graphics. If you're like me and still play openttd / RT3 etc. occasionally, this is pretty cool. I like the vehicles, it's quite nice work on those. It is not a console like 'detailed but cheesy' kind of Gfx, it is not the genre that requires that imo, it just has enough detail where it's needed, like vehicles and cities.
- Interesting economic model. Once you get to understand it the demand based economy is quite simple. I like to follow people to see where they go sometimes, it helped me understand how things work. It's a good challenge to make cities grow, although this means you'll end up with some local lines going into loss, which is pretty realistic I guess.
- For me it's a big plus that it works on Linux. I have been experimenting with living with a desktop Linux for the past few months and it helped a lot to get some nice games on it once in a while. :)
- The modding possibilities look like it will help with replay value. I didn't try mods yet, didn't quite finish" with the stock game yet but I am sure I will at some point. The challenge will just be to find the more finished
date: 'professional' mods.\n- The cargo moving model can be a bit confusing at first
recommended: but it's a nice all around model with the lines
hoursPlayed: frequencies
voteText:
the rule that passengers look to find routes that are within 20 minutes of travel time. It challenges you to build more efficient networks so people can get far by combining the use of different vehicles.
- Dev team seems pretty responsive. In a couple of weeks they released 2 patches that deal with stability issues and help those that have problems running the game in the first place. Although for me it worked out of the box in both Win7 and Ubuntu.

The problems I have:
- Building railroad tracks is very challenging at first

reviewText:
Played this game for a bit now, trying out all sorts of difficulties, settings and map varriants. in overall i would say that it most reminds me of the early days of Transport Tycoon(build, setting, trains -etc), with a mixture of Industry Giants(time line), and Cities in motions based line building and interacting system. the playing it self feel fine and good on higher difficulties the game can become quite challanging as well to make the most of your little company and set-up a profitable line system to not run to deep and debt and fail, although the 3mixture seems like a real good combo there are also down sides, such as the line system not being able to work out how switches interact on multible track stations. which severly limits your options in station building and useage of the stations, when you make a loop track with 2 lines going opposite of one another the game will still run both trains in the same direction which will lead to a full stop since the trains will meet and be stuck since non took a side track. The industry is really limited and seems to dislike trains for cargo, as i placed many times tracks + freight station next to a industry which will then refuse to use the station and line, and even when it uses it, it just does not want to increase in production nor upgrade to match the capacity of your trains on its side. that said, it will interact propperly with trucks(tried on mutlible time era's (1850's, 1900's, 1950's and ++)).
that said in overall i would say the game can be very fun if your a true fan of the series like Cities in motion, Indrustry Giant, Transport Tycoon -etc. so far even before the patch the game ran really stable on my system and never resulted in crashed. big maps can take a while to load but are worth the wait in the end. the start no matter how you start(easy, medium or hard). is a challange, setting up wrong will make you fail and quickly run in debt which then leads to a restart of the game. The one thing that was quite annoying is to see that your passengers will just dissapear from the train/bus they sit in as it moves(had a train with 120passengers leaving the station, to arrive at its destination with just 105passengers).

Pro's:
- Big maps.
- good city devolopment.
- Infrastructure build option.
- Line system.
- loads of options in difficulties and optimizations of the lines/tracks/roads.
- Easy interface.(though feels a bit empty).
- Easy train/bus/truck build mode.
- 3-D
- Music

Con's:
- Industry dis-likes trains.
- Very limited Industry options.
- The build system although good working seems to have troubles adjusting to slightly lower tracks then railroads, making it hard to build tunnels and overpasses easy.(eg. it wont suggest to make a tunnel or bridge if it cant make a on level overpass. but just keeps saying Collision" when you then raise the terain for say a bridge overpass the road will collide with the raised height for the bridge)
- Passengers will just vannish from your trains as they ride.
- Trains/Busses dissapear as purchace options after a X amount of time
date: sometimes forcing you to buy a to expencive train to keep a line open.\n- City's seem to expand away from your station(at least in my games Xd).\n- Not easy to upgrade a train/bus/truck. said item needs to first go depot
recommended: trucks and busses need to be sold(very easy botton for that though)
hoursPlayed: but upgrading a train
voteText: means sending it to station
helpfulPercent: open the train window + Depot window + Buy train window
votesHelpful: Buy a train
votesTotal: remove the locomotive of the said train(sell or move). then place the new locomotive on the excisting train. re-assign its route and send it out again). It in overall is not a dissaster
votesFunny: just time and engery consuming if you get a big network with 50/60 locomotives that need to be replaced since they ran over their livetime span.\n\nIn overall though despite the "flaws" that i have encountered i still love this game and will continue playing it with pleasure
commentsCount: some of my con's might just be from still getting used to the building of. for instance
column16: though seeing somethings added(maybe as optional options(like TDD). where you can keep the old steam locomotives/carriages/trucks/busses -etc would be nice to see

column18: and no Anti-train mentenality on industry would be very nice as well.\nall in all i would still rate this gate with 8/10 cause i just love these games

reviewText:
For those wanting a modern, 3D Open Transport Tycoon Deluxe, Train Fever isn't quite that, but it is close. If you have an open mind and enjoy the genre, you may like TF.

TF has a much more basic gameplay, does things differently from OpenTTD, and has a few technical and gameplay issues, all of which can be disappointing initially if you expect it to play like OTTD. However, if you look past all that and give yourself time to learn how it works, you'll find it to be a solid game at its core with an awesome 3D world to build a transport empire on, without being constrained to a grid. Perhaps both the developers and the modding community will improve it over time, too.

Edit (May 2015): And I was right, the devs have significantly improved TFs performance since writing this.

reviewText:
I have not owned this game very long, but I have to say I am pleasantly surprised how enjoyable and easy it is to play.

The game itself lends elements from various other franchises like the tycoon series, cities in motion and even Railroads (One I love). To start with it is set in the 1850's, but as you play you unlock more vehicles and as you go through the ages you will be able to start in the more modern era's for future games.

The maps are a fantastic size, although I tend to play on Medium size at the moment with flat terrain, still getting used to the game personally. But setting up routes and laying tracks and roads is very simply.

One thing the game lacks is time tables to allow you to set times for trains to use tracks in certain directions which would make building lines cheaper and a little more realistic with the real world, but it would also add more complexity which is why the developers may have left it out and this makes the game very simplistic to play for everyone.

You can check out my You Tube series which I am starting at:

https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL0VtYD7C_Qrc20H7R1uojceCgQEoDY6d2
voteText: 8 of 12 people (67%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Train Fever harkens back to the days of Locomotion and Transport Tycoon, where one was able to build a great transportation empire and accumulate millions or billions while watching a fascinating world grow and become more and more lively. The game world has varying degrees of difficulty and scale, allowing for beginners and veterans with machines varying from toasters to supercomputers to enjoy and play as they like.

Pro's     Dynamic game world with a diverse terrain style and everexpanding population centers
User friendly interface and game mechanics with simple construction tools
Active modding community to be found at  www.train-fever.net [www.train-fever.net]
Extremely beautiful environment and overall a good looking game
Con's
Limited content due to constant developement post-release
Still contains some bugs that need to be ironed out
Lacking variety in transport options and freight types
Overall, I would rate Train Fever as a 7/10 as this game still has very high potential to grow and expand as the developers are very passionate and constantly work to improve it. If you are looking for a game that will suck you in and keep you engrossed on trying to figure out the best way to move people and goods around in the best way possible, while observing and enjoying a beautiful world, then Train Fever should be at the top of your wishlist. At the very least follow the game and its developement, watch some gameplay, and watch it grow into something better than its current state, because this game promises to be great among tycoon fans and casual gamers alike.

reviewText:
The greatest thing of this game is developers continuously update and fix their game.

When the game is just released, game is playable but feels unfinished. Huge lags when your population is large, somewhat lacking variety of vehicles, loading/unloading is unrealistically slow, vehicle replacement is awful, etc.

But now lots of things have been changed. Performance is still needs to be worked but much better than before. Upcoming USA DLC (for free) adds much more variety of vehicles, loading/unloading problem is solved, Vehicle replacement/adjustment still needs to be enhanced but much better. There are still have some problems but devs are aware of them and would be fixed later.

And excellent modability is also be good side of the game. A lot of things are modable and you can see modded vehicles, stations, structures, industries, etc. on fan communities.

Overall, this is a good game. Unlike Cities XXL, it provides patches and updates (including multi-core support) properly with no charge. Unlike Simcity 2013, it provides excellent modability and no online-only BS. provided with much larger map and there is a plan for even larger map size support (not sure they could do that because of the performance issue). Unlike Cities in Motion 2, Dynamic growth is much better and properly worked if you provide good transportation network on your cities. city growth is the best thing among the transportation games I have played and even better than most city-building games in some aspects.

reviewText:
So, you know, this is my first Review ever.

I bought this game a week ago, date of this review is 05.02.2015.

I have, at this time, 88h in the game, and i dont regret one single hour.

This game, as it is, is a fresh feeling game for me. I tried a lot of games, i played a lot of games, and this game feels fresh and accesable to everyone from beginner to veteran.

At this point, the game is very well playable and even after you know the drill of how to run your company, every game you start, feels different and gives you different options.

In my Opinion this game is, atleast for the late game part, for people who got no problem with putting a lot of time into it to get that perect train connection, that perfect busline and so on.

Of course, as it is with new games, it has some trouble to get through.
For me, the most remarkable problem is the late game lag. I dont know if its just for me and my computer, but the Lag in the Late Game ( eg. Big Cities, lots of stuff going on ) gets annoying at time. There are some Bugs, but its nothing that would destroy your gaming experience, for example dont let you do certain things.

I just want to note here, that the modding community does fantastic work and the devs are, at this point, working closely with the community and let them create stuff for the game, that they can then release in future updates and gives the devs more time, for vrious other improved.

So, to sum it up, if you like a solid Tycoon game, that does nothing special, but what it does pretty decent, you like trains etc., you wont regret this game.

reviewText:
Frustrating, steep learning curb, and with some controls that would irk even Mother Theresa, this game will bring you joy and hours of fun once you get the hang of it.

For what it's trying to attemp, it's a great game. It's fun seeing your trains come in and out of your stations, seeing them make a profit, seeing your towns grow and expanding your network. If you enjoy sim games, you'll enjoy this one.

BUT, and it's a big one, it's not an easy game! Have this clear as you make your first map (maybe even the second map), you will fail. The tutorial is mediocre at best. Go online and find tutorials to help you figure things out. Building bridges and tunels is frustrating. Almost makes you feel like you actually need an engineering degree for it. However, once you get the game's logic and figure things out, it will become easier and less infurating. More over, it will bring tons of satisfaction as you (finally) figured out how to build bridges and passes and see them allow your trains continue their routes and bring in profit.

Seriously, once you get things working, you'll have so much fun, a few hours will just banish and you won't even notice. I already have 65 Hrs on this game in just a couple of weeks.

Again, give it a chance. If it becomes too frustating or difficult to play, just look up tutorial online. IT IS NOT AN EASY GAME.

reviewText:
Let me say that many of the issues discussed in other reviews are likely to have been adressed with the various patches, though I will say that this game is well detailed and as such you should have a 1Gig graphics card and 3gb ram minimum.

The maps go from small to large, and I generally find medium good, large can get excessive and small can get crampt once you've connected what you want to.

The only negatives I have are as follows:
> The stuttering at auto-save (which occurs at midnight December 31st) which can make you think the game has crashed
> the lack of variety of vehicles. There's about 5 trucks in the game, and there really should be more. Likewise, there are only a small number (comparatively) of railway engines, despite the variety of real life examples available.
> AI bugs out when altering tracks on a route, even if the route itself isn't broken (e.g. 2 track line reduced to one track temporarily)

reviewText:
Really wanting to like this game, I love the transport tycoon game....but sadly there has yet to be a game that comes close to that classic....this does not either.

Graphics look great, but sadly there is little game play or any real purpose to the game.

Management games like this need to give good feedback as to whether what you are doing is making any real difference and I feel that this information is missing or at best hidden.

Then comes the performance of the game, often missing frames and freezing while selecting menu items...too much work being done in the GUI / event dispatcher thread perhaps?  Even loading a saved game just looks like the UI has frozen and is unresponsive for a couple of minutes, while the game loads

Too much attention to graphics in this game at the very small scale and little to the UI or actual game play in my opinion.

Surely you can improve on, or at least match the classic Transport Tycoon...seriously was that really 20 years ago

reviewText:
I hesitated on buying this game because of the mixed reviews, but ultimately I'm glad that I bought it. It's not quite a Transport Tycoon replacement, but it's a step in the right direction, and there's still a lot of fun that can be had from the game. I don't think the price adequately reflects the value of the game, however, so if it's on sale or if the regular price falls to below $15, it's worth a try.

A number of newer negative reviews point to how the developers plan to discontinue supporting the game in early 2016. While disappointing, the openness about the limitations of Train Fever (particularly in terms of being able to mod elements of the game) gives me hope that a sequel game would be built from the ground up to be modded.

I enjoyed the game. Maybe not as much as I would have enjoyed a perfect, 3D recreation of Transport Tycoon, but I feel satisfied with my purchase. And hopefully the amount I feel that I overpaid for the title is working toward the development of the game I wanted to play. I remain optimistic.

reviewText:
This is one of those games that is never going to escape it's troubled beginnings. There have been some pretty major bugs that have plagued the development of this game and the fledgling developer has done a respectable job at addressing these. At it's core, this is a deep game with a super-steep learning curve and some frustrating interface/gameplay issues. So why is this getting a thumbs up from me? Because despite this, there is still a game that has absorbed me and has given me 80 hours of gameplay.

It's totally sandbox; you're on your own and just poking around with the game doing whatever you want with little other than profit and loss to guide you. But sometimes that's what you want, to just fiddle around and not have some corny derivitive quest thrown at you, or feel as though the goals set by the game are railroading you (pun intended) into playing a type of way you don't want to play.

Big tip: always start with bus routes, get several towns running, then you can start playing around with trams or connecting up compatible industries, expanding until you have enough to start laying track. It's about feeling when you're ready to expand into the next big step, being cautious and backing off if something isn't working.

But, this game would benefit from so much that would take the guesswork out of all this. The developers have obviously tried to go for a more intuitive feel to how you play a transport game, moving away from things like catchment zones when placing stops and the like, which should translate as more realistic: people in real life will travel as far as they need to for public transport, it isn't a binary 'I'm 100 metres away, I'm good to go. I'm 101 metres away, I'm not going that far,' but this does mean that you have no real sense for how far apart stops should be, whether you're bogging your system down with too many stops or missing out chunks of possible passengers because it's quicker to walk. But, in the end, as long as you're making money, who really cares about digital people having to walk a mile to work?

The simulation is broad and develops impressively over time, but again has some issues. Watching towns grow and develop over time is fascinating, although growth tends to often be counter-intuitive, with roads appearing almost randomly. Although you can place roads and have some control over the development of settlements, the lack of accompanying features and relatively minimal feedback into the transport part of the game, besides the ability to add a shortcut to complete a route or upgrade roads to improve speed, means there isn't much reward for getting into this too much.

All in all, the game is playable, albeit with its own little eccentricities. The game is more of a relaxing pass-the-time style than quest-driven adventure through the decades. But, as I've said, it works of you like that kind of game.

The developers are starting fresh with a new game rather than patching and updating this one, which tells me several things. Firstly, they've learnt a lot from this game and have listened to feedback and know that to try and put in all the stuff people want and correct the mistakes that the game has grown up with would be huge and likely game-breaking. But, it also tells me that they are still passionate about this game: they could have done what some many other developers have done, gotten as far as they could with their first attempt and then gone in a different direction. But they haven't. They are building on what they've learnt and starting fresh and in the world of game development, taking years to develop your first game, which is good but bogged down with virtually insurmountable problems, is the easy way to bankruptcy. So, I'm still happy I paid for this game, supported whoever is behind Urban Games, and I'll be there to support their passion for making the right game that they've always imagined when Transport Fever is released.
voteText: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Having owned Train Fever since before Xmas, and played it long enough to earn a reasonable about of money, I have to say I'm finally disappointed. Firstly the time cycles are outrageously swift - it can take days, weeks, decades and months for vehicles to move around the map, and eons to increase product demand of the various services. But what has really broken the camel's back is the road and rail building mechanics.

I've played many similar games, as I'm sure most people interested in the genre have, but laying a roads, rail and especially bridges or tunnels is way too fussy and time consuming. Add that to how quickly the time elapses, many years will have passed whilst you try to understand why portions of a bridge turn red when there's nothing noticeably obstructing it.  Finally, the costs to demolish buildings and road to make way for redevelopment are ridiculously priced. Hundreds of thousands to remove a small building is unrealistic and punishing if you're struggle to make money. All in all, the transport/city building genre is making serious comeback - Paradox seem to be leading the way with the likes of Cities In Motion, and I cannot wait to play their new title Cities: Skylines.

Having watch footage of the latter, when it comes to the simplicity of building and redeveloping, it should be the least tasking portion of a game, and I'm afraid Train Fever has really understood this. I was really looking for to the game and the replayability factor. Since it's been a couple of months since I last tried TF, I had hoped my concerns would have been noticed and perhaps updates to improve the building mechanics - unfortunately the issues remain. I do hope this can be improved upon after this published my review. As things stands, there are better options than Train Fever.

reviewText:
As much as i would like to recommend this game, i can't. If it would be cheaper and in clear early access sale then it would be a great thing to go for. Unfortunately it is sold as a finished product and most of the time on full price.

Game can offer you a decent amount of interest and even some challenge, but so many annoying features and even more so, missin features, are driving you nuts in the later game. Performance gets killed at later game and you may have to wait 10-15 seconds for the calculations to be completed at the end of each month. And since the month is less than a minute long, you get the idea what it is like... And during the month performance isn't that great either.

Lot of graphical bugs, onlogically working build tool, not enough information, no X junctions on railways, no road over rail build etc. are seriously limiting the great fun factor. Selection of vehicles is poor in the main game and only with mods it will get interesting. Also the latest update introduced a feature which doesn't allow player to delete certain roads which game classifies as a main connection. So you can't fully do what you want to do, which is how this game actually was sold at the beginning... So, if you are looking for fun and Transport Tycoon or Railroad Tycoon kind of experience, keep on looking. If you want to be a part of the beta team and get constantly frustrated then join us unfortunates, who went and bought this game at its alpha stage.

Edit 13.01.2015:
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=365263326 Bridge not possible.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=374286491 Excellent AI road…

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=374287200 Need bypass
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=374287539 Tunnel bug

It’s quite clear with all this kind of issues at the game that It’s far from well thought well polished game. Devs should step up and admit that it’s still an alpha at it’s best and should not have been released for at least another year. And that they didn’t plan what they set out to do well enough. Harsh, but true. I really really would like to like this game, but more you play, more you get frustrated with its shortcomings.

reviewText:
There is actually so much to like about this game -
- Line set up is very easy and the way other games should implement it
- Time progression is great - you get to play through various eras
- Town growth simulation seem pretty decent to me - I have no problem with it!
- You get trains, trams, buses, trucks - not just trains!
- Building rail lines are generally easy.

What I don't like about the game:
- There are very few vehicles available.  There's never really a choice to make - there is usually only one tram, one train, one truck or one train to choose (at some points trains give you maybe another option).  It would be great to have more vehicles without mods.
- It's sometimes difficult to bridge or tunnel over or under tracks - it needs to be simpler.
- This is temporary only maybe, but the issue that others reported where the game freezes on the 1st of each month started plaguing me since the update on 30 January.  That's made it almost unplayable for me.
- More in-game tutorials or help is needed or just some easy to understand documentation.  I thought trains were useless until I did some extensive reading and watching loads of Youtube videos to fully understand how industry works.  At least all my trains are profitable now!
- There should be something else to play for - I've pretty much got most of the achievements now - so not too much incentive to play a game.  Missions maybe or scenarios?

Overall though, this game has kept me entertained far longer than most.

reviewText:
I bought the game, installed it and then played every available moment until now, as I'm writing this.

The game is magnificent, the visual engine is beautiful, the camera controls are great, the presentation of the enormous amount of complex data is very user friendly, the game is challenging and rewarding at the same time. I read older reviews mentioning bugs and crashes, I have noticed none of that. The performance is incredible considering the depth and bredth of the simulation. This game is a finished product now.

Instead of mentioning what I miss about the game, I'll just say it's ready for expansions and DLC's, which I will buy. I'm hoping for:
- Boats and seaports
- Complete overhaul of the production and goods side of the game (more towards Sid Meiers railroads than TTD)

I bought it at -66%, but this game is worth the full price.
