reviewText:
I got this game during the Holiday Auction for a VERY good price (thank you devs!) and I have really enjoyed it. I have never played the original Transport Tycoon but I have played my share of OpenTTD as well as games like Cities In Motion. If you like those games, you'll like this. It's as simple as that. Imagine a game like OpenTTD with graphics better than Cities In Motion. I think the overall reviews give the wrong impression. The game needs more development but as it stands now you'll get hours of enjoyment from it if this is your kind of thing.

If you've never played Transport Tycoon type games well then that's another matter. There isn't a lot of hand holding here. If you don't understand something you're going to have to look it up in the wiki. The price is going to be a deterrent to a lot of people as well. As the game stands now I think it's priced a little high and I wouldn't own it if it wasn't for the auction. It needs more content like more industry, planes and boats. Especially boats. But the devs have promised more content is coming and a free DLC was just announced.

If you're on the fence about this game and you haven't played Transport Tycoon, I suggest downloading OpenTTD and see how you like that first. It's free.

reviewText:
Train Fever AKA Stage Coach Fever. Because you will make your early money that way, building train lines is expensive!
I got this during the $11.89 sale. Have played a bit but am making money.
Went with a default map in USA dlc (free). started arround the middle where I could see resources and a factory near a town. Built a Stage coach route in the town with 7 stops. Also built goods stops right next to a coal and iron mine, plus one next to a steel factory. Built a new road direct to the town plus a stop on the edge for dropping off goods. Minimal number of vehicles to start as there is a delay while deman builds.

When I built my stations built them on the outskirts of town so they would be away from any new houses that could appear. Linked them via my stage coach line so people pay me to go to the station. Built another stage line in the next town to funnel passengers between the stations.

Working better than it did in Quill18's youtube play through last year. I like the cancel option when laying track and roads. Would like a warning symbol to indicate a tunnel will be built. Love that the track shows the speed limit as you lay track.

reviewText:
Not really a review as such; but I do wish to point out that this is a 'fun' train 'simulator'.

Sure there are problems with the coding that can bug the hell out of you - no pun intended... honestly!  And there are simulations (name withheld), that perhaps do a better job of 'simulating'.  But hey!   When you get one of those 1950 era electric locos pulling 5 carriages into a station.... oh sigh.... the graphics make up for it.  For the most part I don't mind the way you can/can't change terrain etc. it still looks good to me and works well 9 times out of 10.    I won't go into the 'little' details as enough has been said on those.  What I want to get across to people is it is a 'fun' game with really nice train 'pixels', yes I am using old terminology here but run with it.... I'm old - seriously do young people even 'get' trains? LOL.  And yes I know... using too many quotation marks.

Never played OpenTTD, suspect I'd probably quite enjoy it.   BUT, from the sound of things it is outdated graphics wise, which is why I am happy with  TF.  I like to just sit back and watch the loco pull the cargo up the hill towards the destination.    If there was one thing I'd really like to be implemented, it would be a loco POV.    Other than that, I'm really happy with the game - and yes, as many people have pointed out.... steep learning curve, but well worth it my friends.  AND.... if you are not happy with the vanilla... there are PLENTY of mods that can help with that.

My first 'review'.  But in all honesty this game is a keeper.  I live in Oz, so I pay more for Steam games, and I'm still happy with the price tag.  If I were a Kiwi, I'd be whinging though; because it costs them twice as much in sheep  :-p

reviewText:
I rarely comment on games and I rarely regret buying a game, since I have generally no higher expectations than providing some entertainment for a couple of evenings in exchange of a couple of bucks, but Train Fever made me to comment. This game is a bad joke, unfortunately.

First the name: the game is about road and railroad transportation, unlike its name implies. I wish I had no other problems...
Oversimplified economy and simulation. The paradigm of keep it stupid simple created a Railroad Tycoon in full HD – but the complexity of economy, traffic and simulation has not really been improved from the game title from the early 90s.
Boring gameplay. No challenges other than repeatedly creating bus lines between towns. For me, no local routes could reach any profit, the only thing making sense in the game is to connect different towns.
Boring graphics. No more than a couple of variations of each types of buildings and 3 or 4 differently looking sims made the game tedious in two hours.
Undetailed graphics: A horse wagon with horses but without carman? In 2015? Buses and trains stopping, but no doors opening and noone taking the vehicle or getting off? Joke.
Adding several vehicles to a route will cause them to start at the same minute. Why the hell developers thought I will want to wait with my fingers crossed until my first vehicle reaches 25% progress in its total distance just to manually release the second of the four vehicles on the route and so on?
Weird time simulation: Having build the 6th line with no pause between building lines, and the game reported vehicles on the first line reached their maximum age of 15 years. What?
Unfortunatelly, after a couple of hours of gameplay I could add a dozen more items to this list, but I do not want to waste more time with this game.

If you ever wanted a nice state-of-the-art city builder or transport simulator, and you passed age 6, you do not want to try this game. Feeling so disappointed. :(

reviewText: I love train games.  Sid Meiers Tycoons 1 to Railroads! and a few of the others.  So I can tell you straight off...This is JUNK!  Stay away. reviewText:
Very good thought, but very badly done. Graphic and models are nice, but build anything is really pain in the a**. It really ruins the game, because after several dozens of minutes you will end up in deep depression, because you find out that nice track you built is screwed up and you can't fix it, because game won't let you or don't undestand what you want to do. This bad design feature is even more screwed up by missing UNDO function, which means everything you make bad (rule here is 10 times bad, after that you maybe find the right combination) costs you in game money.

For example, I wanted to replace track junction with single track (detach the branch). I couldn't remove only branch, I needed to remove whole junction and place new short track instead of that deleted junction. But what happened? Game says, I can't place track there because of bad terrain. How it is possible? There was juntion few seconds ago! But what that means for me? I can destroy whole track layout around the junction because I can't fix that missing piece of track. It really pi***d me off and I turned of the game!

It's absolutely unbelievable, that train game is unable to make track crossing, bridge above the another track, or underpass under track. If you want to cross over another line, you need to join them with junction and than make another junction in another opposite direction. this means, it is impossible to cross two perpendicular tracks, because of limited curvature you need lot of space to make those tracks parallel and then turn it again to original direction.

On top of this, bad optimization of this graphicly simple game causes stuttering and big FPS drops even on machine, which is able to run new titles on Ultra. And I can get 60 FPS only from top view. When I move angle to see far, it drops below 20 fps. I really don't get what calculation this game can do on background.

Really, this game should be Early access and there is a lot of work to do. But it seems, devs are not interested to much polishing. But I think they rather work on Train Fever 2, that turning Train Fever into useable game.

So to make a decision - this game has very big potencial, if will be continuously improved in future. But I am afraid, it will not. For now, you will be much more satisfied, if you will play OpenTTD for strategy, or Train Simulator for graphic.

This game gets 5 out of 5 for most dissapointing purchase of the year. There is so much potential here to be a top of the line logistics/transport simulator. Yet I find myself crushed under the weight of the poor interface.

reviewText:
I don't have any other train gaming/sim experience so my opinion is only off of this game and not how it compares to others. Also, I'll add some minor tips/spoilers at the bottom for new players.

The game is fun and initially very challenging. The lack of tutorial information or quality let's play" guides and videos left the learning/discovery pretty much to trial and error. But the process was fun and because it was challenging it caused me to want to do it more. One initial trial game on small/flat/easy allowed most of the advanced features to be figured out. And FYI to all new players the videos and forum posts on creating bus routes and cargo lines was all based on the AI prior to recent patches. My experience did not show those tutorials as being accurate and was a bigger source of frustration than anything in the game itself.

The game is more difficult initially than most maybe
date: but as long as you like the city/world management types of games but on a transportation level you can spend some enjoyable hours on it.  The graphics are good and it is neat to follow your trains/vehicles around
recommended:
especially across that bohemoth bridge you built just for the sake of doing it.

Spoilers/Noob Tips:
• Build rails in small steps to avoid heavy $$ costs.
• Local bus routes are keys to developing a prosperous city
hoursPlayed:
and may not be lucrative themselves.
• Big picture perspective is needed to get you through the long game.
• Not all resources are to be connected to a town or factory
• Most resources should NOT be connected via rail
voteText: early on anyway.\n• Signals and waypoints are your friends

reviewText: Quite enjoyable.  I did not find it as irritating as I thought that there are not many commodities, given that you have to configure your consist with the right rolling stock.  Requiring different stations for goods and people seems realistic to me, and adds limits to work around that make the game more interesting, with more need for crossovers and track/signal management.  Proper signaling is a fun puzzle to solve, and now that you can use a signal or waypoint in a route, you have fine control over which track is used.  Once I figured out the right way to lay track, it became highly enjoyable, determining the best way to navigate a slope.  And it's a gorgeous game.  Perhaps there is more work to do on this title, but I find it to be great in current state.

reviewText:
I'm going to write this review in stages as I feel this game is a slow burner. I've played for just over 10 hours so I'm going to update this review over course of the next few weeks. Please note that I genuinely want to love this game and will probably spend at least 100 hours playing it. For the record I bought the game on sale for about £6.

10 HoursSo far I've found the game confusing and fragmented. the tutorial is a little brief and fundamentally the game isn't very intuitive. I have played several games, often realizing my errors and starting again as a recursive learning process. The game focuses on road and rail transport; so far I've found that creating a rail link between two cities is very profitable but introducing a third city creates a lot of problems due to difficulties managing which trains manage which lines.

I haven't been able to make a profit on inter-city bus lines as people simply won't use the bus service despite using conventional wisdom when plotting the bus route between the various city regions.

Natural resources seem to move at random between starting games. Sometimes lots of natural resources are produced and can be moved between locations and you can make a mint, and sometimes absolutely nothing is produced meaning there is no reason to even bother with them.

Train lines are confusing and creating more complex train routes is convoluted to the point of not being fun. Creating simple A-to-B routes is more profitable and is easier to manage.

ConclusionSo far I've enjoyed the game, in principle, but still feel like there's a huge amount of room for improvement. The basics are there but a lot of time needs to be spent on balancing and tweaking how the game works.

reviewText:
Rule one - buy it ONLY on sale. Not worth 24,99€, all and all 4,99€ is about right.
How would I describe this? If EA would make a tycoon game this would be it. Details are lovely but the cost...
I would say the game is trying too hard even - yes you can check every single pedestrian who has an ID on him, know his job, home, relaxation and shopping habits. So you know where to transport him/her. You can also find the details of the locomotives, carriages, trams and buses are lovely and not just that the cities and cars too. Also the game never crashed on me (running windows 10 64 bit - respect!) Those would be pros.
So what are the cons?
No ships, aircraft, monorails, maglevs, subways, city management, AI, multiplayer. The construction of railways can be a real pain in the butt, endless collisions with terrain, improper angle for road crossings and no matter how much money I invested to a straight line across the map I could never get 300 km/h from the fastest train. And the game feels kind of limited in a sense. Why for example can´t I combine a tram and a train station into one ?
Overall I realize that this game is from a new developer therfore I am not as critical, I believe (rather hope) new features will appear eventually. The game is fun for quite a while if you learn the basics and have a big enough map (reminds me can we have a map editor pretty please?). So if you want to support an indie game wait for a sale(!) and go for it. If you want to have similar amount of fun for free go to google and type in openttd.

reviewText:
Hey everyone,

Well I have just finished a marthon session with this game, I have been playing for about 14 hours straight with couple toilet breaks and grabbing food. I really have to say this is a great game. Its clearly a remake of an old game called Transport Tycoon, which I used to love. This is really everything transport Tycoon has to offer minus the plans and magleve stuff. Its really good fun and little more indepth than TTD (Transport Tycoon Deluxe)

If you like management tycoons and you like trains and trucks and such then really this is game for you. Its first sim game I have played in long time that has held my attention, even to the stage I have not been watching anything on my second screen which I normally do. Its addictive and will keep you coming back for more.

The downsides are this game takes a lot computer resources. so if you computer is slower than prepare for lagging. I have had lag problems and I have pretty high end PC. I think its more issues with programming than actually resources needed. So i hope a patch will come.

Anyways, If you liked theme park, Roller coaster tycoon, Transport Tycoon, Rail road tycoon, then this game is for you!

reviewText:
Train Fever has some flaws and is not a perfect game and lacks some features, but it is the best in the genre, since the last games are either made for childs (looking at you Sid Meiers Railroads) or the last games that have the features, that TF lacks, are very old (RT-Series, Open TTD and others).

PS: I recommend to have atleast 4 GB RAM on your rig. I have 8 GB myself and I have no performance problems at all. So I guess 4 GB is acceptable and not bad, since they announced another performance patch.

reviewText:
Bought this game because everyone says it is like Sid Meiers Railroads, a game I love but can not play since switching to Linux.

Now the only similar thing is the building of train networks between cities and resources but that is where it ends.  The game actually is more complex.  Laying of tracks and setting up trains requires more work than Railroads.

In Railroads you simply lay your track then pick your train and train cars for that section of track.  In Train Fever you must do more, like create a train depot which MUST be connected to the track you want to train to be on.  I could not figure out how to delete a train nor have I figured out yet how to properly connect resources.  BTW, every station MUST be connected to a road which makes placing your tracks even harder.

On top of creating train routes, you also need to create bus routes to move people around each city to your train station.

Unlike Railroads though, there doesn't appear to be any computer players to compete against.  For some people like myself, this can result in a not as fun game but if you are a huge fan of sim city type games where there is no one to compete against then you should enjoy this game.

reviewText:
Train fever is a good and fun game to play overall. It is in my opinion the best train tycoonish game around at the moment and judging from past updates, it should get better with time.

Pros: It's fun! Nice graphics (maps, trains, other vehicules), good audio design, unique music, easy to use building tool.
Cons: Building tool needs more advanced options for more complex networks, performance gets bellow average on large maps in the late game, yearly savegame process is horrid.

TF features a sandbox setup and very good looking proceduraly generated maps. It is really just that though a sandbox and it doesnt feature any tycoon options like campaigns and/or competition. Instead here you are fighting the elements such as hills, rivers, main roads, vehicules decay, etc. The maps look good and not two games are the same since they are generated. If however you are looking for real world maps, you won't find it here.

So what do you actually do when playing TF? You build train, tram, bus and otherwise truck lines to move either passengers and/or cargo around while trying to make enough money to survive another year.

So how is the building tool since it's most of what we do in this game? It's okay but not great.

Building basic rails/roads is easy enough once you learn how the tool reacts to roads and rivers for example. It always try to save you money by proposing the most economical option (bridge, tunnel?, going over?). It also tries to make the best curves and slopes possible automaticaly. Setting up two lines next to each other is also a charm since the tool acts like a magnet and nicely sticks that 2nd line next to the 1st one. For all the basic stuff, it's great.

The building tool really lacks more robust features though, features such as seen in other titles like Cities Skylines. In short, you can't easily cross any other line that already exists. The tool isn't letting the player decide on elevation (page up/down in Cities: Skylines) and there's no way to build X or + connections between two lines. Sure there are tricks around this but it isn't friendly and it makes a mess. As long as you focus on building railroads for EITHER passengers OR cargo, it's fun enough. But as soon as you try to setup multiple lines for BOTH passengers AND cargo, the building tool just falls short. You see, passengers and cargo require different kinds of stations. But since there is no way for a line to go over or under an existing line, it's just not fun to try and build large rail networks for both passengers and cargo. You end up with a spaghetti of parallel lines preventing you from building additional ones.

As a result cargo trains are being left out for the most part and focus is more on passengers ones. It feels like a whole portion of the game is not accessible because the construction tool isn't robust enough and that is my main issue with this one.

Sure experiencing better performance on large maps, being able to buy industries, maybe have credit quotations for loans and see more tycoon features being added would be nice. But first, fix the building tool.

I recommend this game because despite it's obvious flaws, it's fun in it's current state and there are indications it should get even better.

Thumbs up!

reviewText:
Train Fever is a delightfully enthralling management game that you can plunge hours into. I found myself staying up all night in a 'Just One More Turn' sort of way, either because I was desperately trying to keep my fledgling Rail company above water or because I wanted to see if new technology's or expanding profits would allow me to splash out on a new project or to reinvigorate an old one. In terms of management, I've found that learning the basics isn't overly hard, but mastering it is the real challenge. In other management games, I have often found that once you plug the main problem, you have nothing more to do; it's too easy to find the perfect equilibrium and once you've played it once there's little reason to go back and play it again and you rarely had to restart for lack of skill in the first place. In Train Fever, you'll solve a short term problem only to later discover that there's a much bigger long term problem built upon more short term problems. There's lots to manage and lots to do (although not so much as to overwhelm you), and as technology advances new avenues for profit and loss will open up and you'll have to adapt to changing circumstances. Things that are in 1850 unprofitable and infeasible may in 1900 be profitable and very doable.

In short, Train Fever is a game of adaption, of chasing profits and avoiding losses, which can be tough, but very rewarding. You may have to play a failed game or two before you learn all of it's secrets, but a management game in which you instantly have the cure to any ailment is a short lived and unrewarding one.

7/10

reviewText:
Conclusion: awesome track laying game that poorly explains itself (aka has a learning curve)

I am thoroughly enjoying this game but many, many feature only become apparent after looking through guides on steam and after trial and error.

For example I thought there was a cargo staying on the platform bug.. I had 1 route designed like this: pickup cargo, drop off at station 1, pickup cargo again, drop off at station 2. Turns out.. the demand for goods in station 1 is low, so the goods stream in slowly, so the train keeps waiting to fill it up - and never getting to station 2 which is building up. The easy solution: create 2 separate lines and all is good.

So after learning how to lay bus tracks efficiently, place signals effectively, build bridges, ... you end up with a game that's a bit like it suggests in title.. first a fever to overcome it, then a fever because it will suck you back in. Because you can borrow enough money and making it profitable at easy level isn't all that hard, it's more a game about making a beautiful operating railroad than a tough challenge. And that's fine to me.

It's the best game in laying out an efficient routed railway - in any game. I really can't remember that that part was executed that well, and looked this good. I personally love setting the landscape to hilly and create a great flowing double track railroad running through with tight blocks so accommodate all the goods & passenger traffic.

The game runs very well on my GTX 970 at 2560x1024 with everything maxed out.

There are some quirks which I'll hope they fix soon, and I do want to mention that it's good to see the devs have just released another update and support the product:

(1) Keys only work after clicking on the landscape
(2) No mention when trains get stuck (especially after breaking up a section to expand)
(3) The 'two steps'  required is tedious and doesn't belong in games.. figure it out guys
(4) Upgrade a street won't fit while staying a 2 lane road.. really?
(5) Bigger stations please
(6) Allow alternative platforms through alternative waypoints

So all in all it's a very enjoyable game, if you can deal with it's learning curve - and especially when on offer for a special price, it's great value. If you liked transport tycoon, or similar games from Chris Sawyer or Sid Meier ... you'll enjoy this one. I think it's beaten their latest efforts for sure.

reviewText:
I would recommend this game to anyone who likes Tycoon games or OpenTTD. In my opinion this blows OpenTTD out of the water. First of all there's no grid system, so your roads and rail lines are more natural and fluid. Along with that, stations don't have an area of influence. The AI is smart enough to know that, if a station is close enough, it will take supplies and passengers there. The graphics are very good too. It looks great and I run the game on a laptop. I did have issues starting it up because it wasn't choosing the right graphics card, but it's fixed now. The audio is also great, both the sound effects and the music. The music is freaking awesome!

As far as game play goes, if you've played games like this, it's pretty easy to understand.

Now there are a few detractors. It isn't very well optomized for lower end machines, but that's minor as in this game skipping is only an annoyance. There also no in game tutorials, but I see that getting fixed in the future. The biggest draw back of this game is it's price. $35 for a game like this is pretty steep. I'm not too sure it's worth the price tag, so I'd recommend looking for it on sale.

reviewText:
It´s like a barely cut, still slightly crude diamond. It already has some sparkle and fire, you can see it´s potential, but it needs fine cuttting and quite some polish. A swiss programming team of enthusiast train afficionados and the inbuilt moddability give me all the confidence i need to enjoy the game as it is and patiently wait for more.
If you´ve loved TTD and RRT AND are willing to support are game wich finally,  after more than 10 years offers this type of enjoyment with 3D graphics, buy it now.
If you can´t stand games wich are not complete or perfect,  wait for the price to drop and the many updates and fixes wich are sure to come.
Recommended!

reviewText: This game is good. So far I've played it with little lag. That's due to my rig, it's powerful but dated. For the most part everything I've seen is great. The track laying works well, trains make money. Some things I haven't figured out yet but with time I will. My main complaints are the same as others that I believe the devs will fix. The save file issue and the lack of ability to turn off auto saves bothers me. Not enough to give this game a negative review. Also some of the passengers on the longer distance trains dissapear. Can't easily replace vehicles. Can't easily upgrade stations. But overall I love this game. I've been watching it for quite some time now and even watched most of the Beta Testers play it. No game these days is released without bugs. I expected that. Now I'm waiting for the devs to hopefully fix it soon and I believe they will. This game has, I believe, a bright future ahead of it. Some people want to stick to the old games that they know will work and that's fine to me. I on the other hand have been waiting for a game with the feel of Locomotion but more modern graphics to come out. For years no one has taken on this genre and taken it seriously. Sid Miers Railroads was dumbed down too much for my taste. RRT3 lacks the ability to build a detailed rail network. And the graphics for Transport Tycoon hurt my eyes. I'm going to stand by this game. The cities are fun to watch grow. The industries react to supply and demand which is cool to me. You don't just move cargo there has to be a need for it, just like in reality. I'm going to continue to play this game and delete however many auto saved files I have too lol. I hope people wont shun this game for first impressions with some bugs. It's just a small group of people working on this and I personally say thank you to them for this game. For going into what seemed to be a dead genre to the gaming industry and making a beautiful game.

reviewText:
I lovely sedate transport building game where laying tracks is an art. Even on flat ground it takes skill to get track laid without excessive filling or cutting. Then you have to think about linking up stations and bridges, and also linking up your trains to your town road systems. I have played a few of these games before and this one is really nice. The trains take a while to fill up with people, there is loads of steam and smoke when they stop, the graphics look lovely expcially in the towns with the horse pulled carriages, and there is quite a bit to think about.

If you want a fast game where you can layout massive circuits in a few minutes this game isnt for you. You really need to conctrate on what you are doing and plan ahead in this game.

I is rather basic at the moment in terms of varied gameplay though. There arent any challenges other than not going bankrupt, and it all revolves around configuring your transport links and routes. But I am sure thios game will continue to grow into a really nice game. So I would say its a great start, the beginning of a potentially great game. But I would say for what is here at the moment its a bit pricey. A couple of free content packs might really make this game very good value though devs!

reviewText:
If you like trains and all that goes with building a succesful railroad. Then this game is for you.

You can not just drop a line and sit back and watch. It has to be planned along the contours of the map thereby travelling from A to B is not a straight line.Bridge and tunnel building all give to the trials and tribulations the real Railroader faced.

Then you have to build up your cities. Bus and tram routes have to br planned to give the most return.

The art of building up your supplies of goods do you use road or rail can you get raw materials to your manufacturer and then supply your industries.

All good fun and a game to be played in the long term , no guns rockets or dragons just your brain against the computer.

Not for the wierdos who want dragons and elves and hobbits or gun carrying  super freaks. This game requires intellegence and thought.

reviewText:
I am only recommending this game on potential, not how it is at the moment.

Pro's
It looks really quite nice, not quite as pretty as the 'tilt shift photography' method of Sim City but certainly passable, i would say it's probably around the same as SM Railroads +
If you have played CIM the lines are going to be very familar to you +
The framework for a replacement Railroad Tycoon 2 is definately here +

Current Con's
It has an internal logic, but the developers don't want you to know what that might be.  So you'll end up with trains using what track they feel like or sitting at lights for no reason at all. --
No significant tutorial, coupled with a entirely opaque UI, be prepared to spend time on goggle learning how to play. -
Track laying is both powerful and at the same time utterly dreadful, it forces you towards level tracks, generally good, but it will give you bridges for some drops, tunnels for gentle hills.  You can get around this, but you have to very carefully lay small segments of track, obviously you start to lose sight of the other station. -
Making money is very hard, at least at the begining the maintence costs are simply punishing, trains are a giant money sink, road transport makes money, rail transport costs money, -
Industry model seems broken to me, like the above, I am sure there was a reason my carts were sat waiting for coal, but the game wasn't about to tell me. -

This really isn't ready for prime time, i could have added more issues, but it seems unfair, the framework for a good, possibly great sim is here, but this really isn't it.

I would wait for patches and/or mods before purchasing.

reviewText:
Initially I didn't get it because it is different from the old tycoon games. Then I figured it out (read some of the guides)... and now I'm hooked!
Game economics and growth are more realistic. Think closely about supply and demand, supply chains, and how stimulate growth. And be careful with choosing which means of transport to use and start small, then grow it (hint: trains are expensive to run so you want them to fill up).
Amazing details and it feels like you can do anything. As you travel through time, everything changes.
If you were hooked on the old railroad games and need a greater challenge, then this is the game for you.

reviewText:
Played for a few minutes, maybe I should write something down.

1.  It immediately reminds me of Transport Tycoon Deluxe, as well as the 3D attempt (3DTT) fell through some 15 years ago.  The depot placement is surely 3DTT, and the financial setup is similar to TTD.

2. The line feature is the most prominent feature of the game.  It has its limitations though, such as cargo will vanish if the player removes the associated route.  Therefore route planning is essential.

3. Station mechanism has a bit of problem.  Train stations have to be physically connected in order to exchange cargo.  This make putting a station in the middle of a built-up area unwise.

Generally a good game, and hopefully this game can sooth the sorrow of 3DTT not making it.


(v1:  2015-10-21)

reviewText:
1. Frustrating. Non-existent tutorial makes this a tough game to jump into straight away. After spending an evening watching YouTube videos, I was finally able to get a business up and running and breaking even. Raw materials are scattered across the map, as expected, but the factories are also stuck out in the middle of nowhere, instead of congregating in the industrial sectors of your towns. Not having the ability to build new factories, where you really need them, is also extremely irritating.
2. Fun. Not nearly as playable as Sid Meiers' Railroads and with no real goals or opponents it boils down to a straight builder. If you like SimCity or Banished, this is for you.
3. UI. Horrible. To track performance and profitibility you need to have several windows open which cover most of the play area. With no ability to push these windows over to a second monitor you have to pause often to review your status. When new trains become available there is no accompanying information to let you know if they are passenger or freight trains.

I really was expecting more. Hopefully there are expansions, updates or mods out there to make this a better, more satisfying gaming experience.

reviewText:
I was on the fence for a bit as to if I should purchase this. The mixed reviews made me cautious, but experience has told me that some of the worst rated games have been the most enjoying to me personally, so I've learned to ignore them (for the most part). I bring to you now a cautionary tale of my journey.

Day 1: I took the plunge and bought the game. Being a conductor for Union Pacific, I have a good idea of how railroads work. This game caught me by surprise. Everything in the game world is modeled realistically. Everything from the trains, industries, supply/demand, and even the individual people who walk on the street have a home, a work place, and a leisurely activity location.

Day 2: I made a large map with some hills using the USA DLC. I built a passenger line from San Diego to Temecula, the year is 1850. I enjoy the little steam engines and the simpler way of life. Horses moved my little village people to and fro. And I was satisfied.

Day 3: I've been up all night trying to establish a profitable passenger connection to Modesto and refine and upgrade my rail network to incorporate and support newer rolling stock and locomotives. My wife says I've been on the computer too much.

Day 7: My wife is worried, she says I haven't spoken to her in days. In more important matters, I've recently connected the San Diego oil fields with an oil production site. I've linked it's distribution to San Diego, Temecula, and Minniapolis - effectively shutting down and putting the local lumber company out of business. I feel invincible.

Day 12: I've lost my real life job. I've found that my virtual empire needs me more. The year is now 1950 and my rail empire now spans over a dozen cities with a conglamoration of rolling stock with newer as well as vintage locomotives plying the lines. I've established a second oil field in the town of Houston, which now distributes to over 7 outlying cities.

Day 21: My wife has left me and taken my 2 year old son. Now that I have some peace and quiet, I can continue my domination of the digital world. My diet now consists of purple coolaid and stockpiled beef jerky that I kept getting for christmas.

Day 30: My body is weak, I smell, I'm hungry, and the sunlight coming through the window hurts my eyes. But in other news, the year is now 2025 and there are but 2 cities left to conquer. They have remained untouched due to their inaccessible locations at high elevations. I plan to conquer them with trucks and busses and then tie them into the rail network.

Day 42: I have achieved perfection. Every road and rail network is upgraded. Every line is profitable. Every train is properly balanced.

Day 43: I've ventured out into the real world again. My body resembles that of a holocaust victim. I decided to go to Subway for a bite to eat. Standing in line, gazing at the menu, I decided to order a foot-long steak and cheese sandwich. As I sat down, I could hardly wait to bite into the sandwich. As my teeth sank into it's toasted, warm, and soft outer buns, a tear rolled down my cheek - not because I had forgotten how good real food tasted, but because I had remembered that I had forgotten to upgrade the old railroad crossing in San Diego.

11/10 I would buy this again.

reviewText:
Fun, easy to learn and nice graphics! I can absolutely recommend this transport-(mamagement-) simulator!

Short description: Quite like Transport Tycoon, but better graphics and better gameplay. For guys who know Simutrans, Train Fever is the a little less complicated, but easier and graphically more enjoyable alternative.
It's basically a complex 3D transport simulation game, where you can build and expand (reinvesting your revenue) your own transport network across about 100 Years in a random generated map.

Positive:
+ Easy to learn, so it's also easy to build your own transport-worlds full of marvelous train lines, for goods or passengers.
+ Best graphics for a Transport Tycoon I've seen so far.. Really great for rail-fans, thanks!
+ Enjoyable from the 1 hour to the 200 hour of gameplay (and further, if the developers continue imporving the game).
+ You can and have to really build everything along the railway line, so stations, slopes, bridges, tunnels, everything has to be done by you. You can build everything exactly as you want it (if you earned the money). Still (especially compared to other such simulations) it's easy to learn and sooo much fun!
+ The train and tram models (mostly swiss) you can choose from are gorgeous!

Negative:
- Some bugs are still in the game (eg. occasionally building tools do weird stuff), but most of the severe bugs have been repaired quickly. The developers are quite active.
- The user interface is not very nicely designed, but you'll get used to that after 10 mins.
- Only trains, trams and buses so far (no ships, planes, underground trains, cable cars)..
- Not many train models to choose from yet, but the ones they have are very well modeled!
- No DLCs yet, but the still small community is quite alive.
- You can not drive the trains in your world. But the graphics from looking at them should already warm the heart of any train-fan.
- Passenger behaviour is not yet as complex as in Simutrans Experimental, so sometimes it's not 100% realistic... But for most purposes it works even better than most other transport simulations.
- Only stations with up to 5 tracks and no underground stations or big city infrastructures available yet. So in its current form it's more like a transport simulator for rural railway networks, not megacities yet.

Conclusion: It's great fun for railway fans! With Train Fever I can finally my own beautiful alpine railway landscapes - and gampeplay is really fun... I love it. Buy it..

reviewText:
Wonderful transport simulation game, amazingly beautiful and fun to play. The game feels very realistic, much less schematic in depicting the physical reality than, say, OpenTTD (it seems that some people dislike the limitations based on real-world constraints, such as allowed rail curvature and slope, but I enjoy this realism a lot).

It looks like the most complaints about this game and negative reviews came from the initial release, and most issues have been solved by now.

I give Train Fever 8 stars out of 10. If you are like me a long-standing fan of Transport Tycoon, TTD and OpenTTD, I definitely recommend you to give Train Fever a try.

reviewText:
It's not Transport Tycoon. Yet. And look at the differences between OTTD and the original Transport Tycoon Deluxe. These things come over time. These guys know that community development is key, and mod support strengthens the game immensely.


Whilst not perfect, the game fares really well overall and is the first game to do free (non-tiled) track building really nicely. And it's quite hard to master, even for a TTD-veteran. There's some more room for features and content, but that's always good, and they're continously working on the game, still. Also the music's spot-on, and really nicely following the TTD/Locomotion/RRT-style of smokey and jazzy bluegrass-esque mixtures.

If you're into trains, or at least into transport sims, you're not gonna regret this. There's a nice community behind it, and there's tons of mods already around. But the vanilla game - plus the free DLC, not to forget - are good enough to have a great deal of fun with. These games are rare enough in itself.

reviewText:
This is definately no Railroad Tycoon program.

It is much more simplified.
In a way it isn't even a Train Simulator.  In fact you don't even have to run any trains if you don't want to.
You can run a Stage Line instead and still make millions of dollars.  Of course you can run both trains and coaches.

The trains are hard to operate unless your simply running pont to point.  The signaling system is too simple to be of much good if you try running multiple trains on one track.  There is only one size Train Station, BIG.  There is no small Train Station that you can place at a distant Industry. There are three different sizes of train stations but even the smallest takes up space equal to 3 city blocks. They look silly sitting next to a dinky logging camp.

The industries are spread haphazardly about the map.  You might find an Oil Well but the Refinery could be halfway across the map.  It isn't cost effective to service since comodities bring very little cash compared to Passengers.  You can of course but it will take years to get a return on your investment.

Cargo hauling by Horsedrawn wagons or Freight Trucks is more cost effective than trains but unlike trains they can't haul freight to an industry and then pick up the goods produced. For example a Truck delivering lumber won't automatically change and take a load of goods made from the lumber.  You have to buy a seperate truck for goods, Not very realistic.

Graphics are pretty bad,  Inside towns or cities it's not bad but out on the highways and tracks it's bad.  The land is bare and boring with an occasional tree or two.  Even shades of green would be better than dirt and sand.

If you use a Trackball or a wheel less mouse you will have problems scrolling some popup windows once you exceed 9 Lines.  Scrolling these windows requires a Mouse wheel.  Poor design.

Now you might be wondering why I recommend this game.

I'm enjoying running Stagecoaches and fine tuning the profit making.
I like being able to zoom in and see my coaches moving along and looking at all the people inside towns.
Cute things like watching a coach stop to let pedestrians cross the street.

I'm sure to discover new things as I play along.  I'll add them here if I do.
I'm having fun,  so yes I recommend it.

reviewText:
The game have pretty graphics thats all. And because of that it makes you wanna play more and more. The trains are very detailed, the wagons, the sounds. But don't bother getting it. Another unfinished game on Steam.


- The game lags absurdly. My machine can run GTA V at full specs no lag. But cant run this game on a medium sized map with 20 trains running without lagging every scroll of the map. The devs already released 5 patchs to improve performance, still same thing. It will never improve. The engne is broken.

- The cargo system is broken. No mods are able to fix that. The industries only produce goods if the entire industry chain is linked. That causes 2 main problems: industry chain in the game is ridiculously simple. The most complex industry you have is: Coal + Iron = Steel = Goods. That's all. Second problem is that if you want to make any changes in your line (put a more modern train, remake a connection) all the industries affected by that line will drop production to zero. Because they cant wait a second more than 20 minutes to receive goods. And to increase production back it take years. That means you lose a profit of millions for years and go bankrupt, game over.

- Game balance is horrible. Put trains, trucks, buses and trams in one game was a huge mistake. A bus makes profit driving a feel blocks, to simulate a town. So if you want to get filfy rich you make a bus drive between two cities and you get more money than a train. Cities are too small, train stations are extremelly huge considering the map size.

- There are way too many industries in the map. You can make the entire thing on trucks and buses, no need for trains. Of course, neither way is possible because after you buy your 10th truck or 10th train the game will lag till you want to punch the screen.

- The game has nothing but connect point A to point B and look at pretty graphics. RRT2 from 1998 has 10x more features (a decent financial report, stock market, buy and sell companies, competition, etc). Well it has less features than Locomotion (a game that Chris Sawyer made while sleeping). Focus too much on graphics all the rest is left aside.


It took me years to write this review, but I cannot avoid this conclusion. The devs are dedicated but unfortunately they made a big mistake on development. I don't know why small devs make their own engine. Use Unity or other. CO made the same mistake with Cities in Motion 1. Very nice graphics, thats all. Lag as hell. If its a small team use your resources to finish the game, not start from scrach.

Not wroth it.

reviewText:
Wonderful transport simulation game, amazingly beautiful and fun to play. The game feels very realistic, much less schematic in depicting the physical reality than, say, OpenTTD (it seems that some people dislike the limitations based on real-world constraints, such as allowed rail curvature and slope, but I enjoy this realism a lot).

It looks like the most complaints about this game and negative reviews came from the initial release, and most issues have been solved by now.

I give Train Fever 8 stars out of 10. If you are like me a long-standing fan of Transport Tycoon, TTD and OpenTTD, I definitely recommend you to give Train Fever a try.

reviewText:
It's not Transport Tycoon. Yet. And look at the differences between OTTD and the original Transport Tycoon Deluxe. These things come over time. These guys know that community development is key, and mod support strengthens the game immensely.


Whilst not perfect, the game fares really well overall and is the first game to do free (non-tiled) track building really nicely. And it's quite hard to master, even for a TTD-veteran. There's some more room for features and content, but that's always good, and they're continously working on the game, still. Also the music's spot-on, and really nicely following the TTD/Locomotion/RRT-style of smokey and jazzy bluegrass-esque mixtures.

If you're into trains, or at least into transport sims, you're not gonna regret this. There's a nice community behind it, and there's tons of mods already around. But the vanilla game - plus the free DLC, not to forget - are good enough to have a great deal of fun with. These games are rare enough in itself.

reviewText:
This is definately no Railroad Tycoon program.

It is much more simplified.
In a way it isn't even a Train Simulator.  In fact you don't even have to run any trains if you don't want to.
You can run a Stage Line instead and still make millions of dollars.  Of course you can run both trains and coaches.

The trains are hard to operate unless your simply running pont to point.  The signaling system is too simple to be of much good if you try running multiple trains on one track.  There is only one size Train Station, BIG.  There is no small Train Station that you can place at a distant Industry. There are three different sizes of train stations but even the smallest takes up space equal to 3 city blocks. They look silly sitting next to a dinky logging camp.

The industries are spread haphazardly about the map.  You might find an Oil Well but the Refinery could be halfway across the map.  It isn't cost effective to service since comodities bring very little cash compared to Passengers.  You can of course but it will take years to get a return on your investment.

Cargo hauling by Horsedrawn wagons or Freight Trucks is more cost effective than trains but unlike trains they can't haul freight to an industry and then pick up the goods produced. For example a Truck delivering lumber won't automatically change and take a load of goods made from the lumber.  You have to buy a seperate truck for goods, Not very realistic.

Graphics are pretty bad,  Inside towns or cities it's not bad but out on the highways and tracks it's bad.  The land is bare and boring with an occasional tree or two.  Even shades of green would be better than dirt and sand.

If you use a Trackball or a wheel less mouse you will have problems scrolling some popup windows once you exceed 9 Lines.  Scrolling these windows requires a Mouse wheel.  Poor design.

Now you might be wondering why I recommend this game.

I'm enjoying running Stagecoaches and fine tuning the profit making.
I like being able to zoom in and see my coaches moving along and looking at all the people inside towns.
Cute things like watching a coach stop to let pedestrians cross the street.

I'm sure to discover new things as I play along.  I'll add them here if I do.
I'm having fun,  so yes I recommend it.

reviewText:
If you're like me, you've played OpenTTD and always wished for a similar game without the grid. This is sort-of that game. I probably would not have bought this at full price; as many other reviewers have noted, it feels incomplete. Track-building needs to be refined, more industry chains need to be added with more variation between them. There's no texture for transitions between the two main road types, which has no consequence on gameplay but agitates me to no end. The random maps all feel the same, and the game badly needs a map editor and Workshop support.

The UI is surprisingly good, with a couple exceptions. The developers clearly have learned from OpenTTD and tried to minimize needless clicking as much as possible. The graphics are technically great but artistically just OK, though the smoke from steam trains always looks beautiful. Most importantly, it scratches the itch for a modern 3D transportation game, and at sale prices, it's worth the cost for me.

People who are into transportation games to make rediculously complex networks *might* not find this worth it. Players who aren't familiar with the genre will probably end up bored or find it takes too long to learn. People who like transportation games because YAY TRAINS!!! should probably get this, just don't set your expectations too high.

I get the feeling the developers have the design part down pretty well, and hopefully their next game will give them more resources to execute that vision. I look forward to it.

reviewText:
When I first played this game, I found it frustrating and clunky. I thought I'd do the right thing and give it 12 months to see if it got better and from what I can see it didn't. As someone who was a massive fan of TTD almost 20 years ago and in the last few an even bigger fan of OpenTTD, I was hoping this could be something similar with improved graphics.

I will give it some credit, the graphics are great. Beautiful models and nice, if not largely empty, maps but it goes downhill from there. I found the total lack of a tutorial map a massive turn off and found it insulting that the developers had the shear audacity to link to player made guides when I needed in depth help. There was a simple help tutorial which was vague, just lines on message box and no pictures to illustrate if you weren't sure. I found trying create lines difficult and not always obvious as to why it worked sometimes and not other times and that when I was trying to added new stations to a line it would just select the station instead of adding it.

Ultimately this game is definitely not worth $30, and honestly I would still feel like I got ripped off at $10. I'm going to put this in the Got burnt hoping this game would be like something else" pile. What saddens me most is that I'm a huge fan of the Business Simulator genre that has fallen into obscurity in the last 10 years but it's games like this that give the genre a bad reputation and stop other

reviewText:
Gamedesign is very solid and it makes much fun building the traffic lines and earn money with them.
The vehicles are designed well and with the USA DLC theres even more diversity. However i still think vehicle running costs could be balanced a little better.
Building train tracks(double+) is also a little frustrating sometimes when you can see no logic reason why the terrain can't be aligned and will drive you nearly nuts when trying to connect two stations through a tunnel or when the station istelf has to be in hilly terrain.However after some time practicing one is able to mostly avoid such situations.

Well considering only Gameplay/Design i would give the game a 8/10

BUT

There is the technical side that is pretty much a gamebreaker. In the Endgame or roughly after 1950 when the Cities start expanding the frame rate Drops significantly (for me from 60FPS frame cap to 8-15 FPS depending on camera view)
and the autosave at the end of the year tends to stop the game for several seconds) Having the line overview open or a train window (the one where the train is viewed in the frame of the window) will drop the frames even more.
All in all it can be called a slideshow.
All you can do against it is play on small maps then the performance drops are kept at bay, but with a middle to large map (which are much more fun) you are pretty much doomed.
The perfomance issues seem to be caused by poor programming since cpu Utilization never rises above 20-25% and the graphic card is only utilized to a third of its potential.So even having a pretty high end system won't help much, since only 1or 2 Threads seem to be used by the game.
In my case its an FX8320(overclocked to 4.5ghz) paired with gtx 980 ti.

my final Rating would be a 2/10 considering perfomance drops in the endgame nullify the fun of the work you invested in the Previous 100-150 simulated years.
This Review was made with the latest patched version.

reviewText:
I really liked Sid Meier's Railroads. When I discovered Train Fever and decided to buy it, I really hoped it would be a worthy successor, as Sid Meier's Railroads is pretty much an antique by today's standards. I've been editing this review quite a few times as I've been playing and learning the game, and after playing for around 25 hours, I believe I finally have a good enough perspective to give a thorough and fair review.

The positive points:
1) The game is, or at least *should be*, fun to play, if and when it works properly. Needless to say, I wouldn't have wasted 25 hours playing a game I didn't enjoy playing, so that fact speaks for itself.
2) The vehicles look good, graphically. I can't judge for myself how accurate and realistic they look, but by reading other reviews and comments, I got the impression the developers did quite a good job about that.
3) The soundtrack is nice and fun to listen to while playing.


The negative points:
1) The performance is *really* bad. I have a decent PC. Nothing too fancy or cutting-edge, but enough to run most modern games smoothly on medium-high settings (Cities: Skylines, for one). Train Fever, on the other hand, barely works. It starts out okay, but as soon as the cities get a little larger than their starting size and there are over 30-40 vehicles moving, the game stutters constantly. I read somewhere that the main reason for that is that the game only uses one CPU core, as it doesn't support multi-core. All in all, the game seems not to use the hardware resources it has, which implies poor programming.

2) The interface is very uncomfortable, there are no tutorials or in-game beginner-friendly guides to help understand how the game works. The information screens are vague and confusing. You pretty much need to learn the basics by trial and error, which is quite frustrating, considering you also have to struggle with the lousy performance while at it. I work as an accountant and I deal with companies' financial reports on a daily basis, but even I have been having troubles figuring out the financial data the game gives me about my company. Totally counter-intuitive. Needless to say, I know practically nothing about engineering or anything related to trains, which seems like a serious disadvantage when playing such a game. I've managed to improve a bit in my track building skills, but I'm still pretty clueless about how the cargo industries work, and the little I do know - I had to learn from a guide I read online. The little information the game gives about that is so cryptic, that it made me wonder what the developers had in mind when they released the game in such a state.

3) Not enough content. There are no AI competitors, no random events, no side-quests, missions or anything else to make the game more interesting. While the game could be interesting enough without all those things (if it worked properly), they would sure be an important addition.

All in all, I only recommend this game to hard-core fans of the genre, and even then - I'd suggest waiting for it to go on sale. For anyone else, I'd suggest to pass on this game. Not worth it.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I can't recommend Train Fever even though I'd like to. Train Fever can be a fun, charming game at times. It's beautiful to look at. Watching your train go across the countryside or following a tram through your city is just beautiful. It's relaxing (when it works). It's charming and I really gravitate to that. I like the ability to create my own transportation networks, plan routes and create my own little empire.

But it's fundamentally broken.

1. Performance is exceptionally poor. By the time you get to 1950, expect your computer to stutter badly even on small maps. This has been only somewhat fixed in subsequent patches.

2. Game mechanics either don't work correctly or are so poorly explained as to be frustratingly obtuse. Some things - like resource production or auto-replacing vehicles - only work sporadically. Others like city growth and even how to set up signals are so obtuse they're not fun. They could have done a much better job of either providing more information on screen or perhaps a better tutorial. But there are some quite un-fun mechanics in here.

3. Gameplay is fairly limited. There are precious few industries, a static map (there's never a new resource node or challenge you have to react to), limited supply chains, etc. All of thise makes for a less-than-ideal experience. Transport Tycoon this isn't, even if it says it would like to be. There are no ships, no planes either. In short, nothing dynamic happens even though the time period encompasses the Industrial Revolution, 2 World Wars, etc. That's a major flaw.

4. Probably the biggest killer is a lack of feedback to the player. There is very limited information. Want to know how many people use a bus stop? Sorry. Want to know why someone decided to walk or drive to work? Sorry. Want to know where that passenger is headed? Sorry. Your information is exceptionally limited and it makes problem solving pure guesswork.

This was so close to being good. But I think what may have happened is that they ran into such a roadblock with performance issues they never got around to really polishing the gameplay. It's quite a shame.

reviewText:
In two words: for kids who love CHOO-CHOO and WROOM-WROOM, but no deeper.

This game is raw and tasteless, because developers of this economic simulator can't into economy.

A CEO have to define every sneeze in company, as like that company have no managers. You can't make mixed routes like in Railroad Tycoon 3 or Locomotion, when a vehicle take one cargo in A, drive to B, unload it, take another cargo, drive to C, change to another type of cargo, and deliver it to D, when it takes cargo needed in A. Not only specialized things, like oil tank or hopper, but every multi-purpose vehicles have to drive from A to B with only one predefined type of cargo and return from B to A empty. You can define a complicated route, of course, but it is useless in this game, because your vehicle can haul only one type of cargo, defined by you.

A random industry prefers to close, rather than load your carriages, if you don't deliver it's products in 20 minutes. What, your train can easily handle industry's annual production, and wait for loading? Doesn't matter, we are closing!

And your vehicles can't just wait for any load and then depart with 1-2 boxes, they will die waiting for full load. Or there is another option - the first one takes what was already produced, then an empty procession of cars passing an empty station.

I recommend to replay RRT3, instead of bying this.

reviewText:
Unless you want to experience countless hours of frustration and disappointment stay away from this. The construction process is undoubtedly the worst and most ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ever devised. The only thing you can do if you want to avoid mind boggling snafus is to lay a few single tracks and watch the trains as they roll.

This game is a crossbreed between  Locomotion and Cities in Motion and tries to accomplish everything but fails miserably in every aspect. Track layout is like in Locomotion except you have more chances to win the Nobel prize than to build a tunnel. Junctions can only be very far apart so you'll have a difficult time building a non-trivial rail network on the very limited space and uneven terrain. Train routes are like the subway lines in Cities in motion so all trains on a route will use the same line in a station regardless of how many there are. Every time you alter a route with so much as a signal it will be reset and the passengers will disappear. They also disappear from the trains while they are transported. You can't build roads over rails, you first have to demolish rails, place the road and then build the rails again. You can't demolish reasonable rail segments the game arbitrarily chooses large chunks and even both rails if they go over a road or there is a junction. Terraforming is horrible as you level terrain, you can only raise, lower or 'smooth' it and only in three circular brushes although all buildings and tracks are rectangular. You can build while the game is paused but this will still erase the passengers waiting at stations and confuse the trains.

There are only few vehicles and their running costs are excessively high, especially for trains. Mines and oil wells produce too little and have to be 'persuaded' to transport their cargo with your vehicles which takes a few years during which you'll only register big losses. You can't set the price for the

The ui is ghastly and cumbersome. The game freezes for many seconds at times and this gets worse as the game progresses.
Documentation/help is missing in action. Not even a few lousy tooltips like transport tycoon had 20 years ago.


It's such a pity there are so many serious flaws with a game which looks so good and has such detailed models and nice sounds and lighting. I really enjoy watching the vehicles move around and use the follow camera but whenever I have to build something it makes me so mad that i want to crash a few trains (which you can't do in this game by the way).

reviewText:
It is absolutely impossible to get started without serious planning. This makes this game an absolute nightmare.
If you are into planning and like to spend hours before you can enjoy anything, then by all means purchase.

As far as I am concerned this is a no go if you want to have fun. You are always referred to external walkthroughs and guides, which means that little or no thought was going to this product documentation.

There are no tutorials in game, the menus are clunky at best (big icons, probably for tablet users without any tooltips).
Understanding slopes and how to deal with them is made very difficult in this game. On the plus side the graphic details is very good, but that is all.

All in all, do not buy for more than EUR 2.

reviewText:
Plus:
+ This is one of the best replicas of TTD(Transport Tycoon Deluxe) I've played to date.
+ game is simple, easy to manage
+ easy to build railroads
+ an already present road system so you only need to plop down stations and depots and you are good to go road side
+ really nice order setting menu for your vehicles
+ an interesting mechanic that somewhat forces you to build both a rail and bus system in a city and they work off eachother to make more money.
+ easy to replace vehicles
+ graphics

Minus:
- some factories dont produce goods if they don't have anywhere to deliver within a close enough radius
- this does not change even when u make a station for said factory and there is nothing in the game implying it
- poor terraform tool and no way to make elevation change projections before building, to save money
- no easy way to make overlapping tracks or bridges over lines
- poor optimization

I would give this a thumbs up and play the game a lot more than I have if it did not crash for me repeatedly, shortly after 1900, on two separate playthroughs. Worth a buy for under $8, but I don't think there is any guarantee the game will run well in to the late game.

reviewText:
This is not a newer and prettier OTTD! As much as they tried to recreate the experience, and they came close, trying to play with no mods (to get achievements) is beyond frustrating. To lay one section of track can sometimes take forever because the building system is just not intuitive, refined, or even understandable at times! This one issues (and there are only 2 or 3) takes away from the game so much its not even enjoyable, and I have tried to play thru this ONE issue. 136 hours on record.

If you don't care about any of the achievements (and other things in game), then you can enable mods to by pass the FRUSTRATION of not being able to delete the game generated roads (because they are main connections, and you spend an hour drawing OTHER MAIN CONNECTIONS that never work so you can get the useless road out of your way!). There have been many times Ill just quit in the middle of a game out of frustration.

It is pretty, simple, and addictive if you vaguely enjoyed OTTD. But this ONE issues needs to be addressed before its really playable. Sadly until then, I would have to recommend to not buy it, unless its on sale for $5.

reviewText:
Great game with lots of potential (mods!). However, there are also some very weird, random, and obvious shortcomings (some are really really annoying) in this game, such as:

- No real tutorial available, while the game has a steep learning curve.
- No background sounds available, which is a big shortcoming!
- No clear way to tell where people want to go to/work/leasure, which requires a lot of expensive trial and error. Use the Traffic Giant method by showing through colors where people work. Now only a 'Land Use' map is available, but it doesn't mean people actually work next door (why have a transportation simulator otherwise).
- No minimap in the game, a big shortcoming with the huge maps.
- When you have many lines, it becomes very hard to distinguish where lines are headed on different tracks, especially when you are colorblind. Would be better if you could highlight certain lines more clearly.
- Very few vehicles available in the game, although modders are working to change that
- You can construct railway crossings over roads, but not the other way around, which is SUPER ANNOYING
- Only straight railway stations? Really??
- Upgrading railway stations is incredibly annoying
- Depots are one way only, which is terrible in case you have to replace a train in late game. Drive through depots are more realistic, and much better.
- For some weird reasons,you cannot construct X" crossovers for rails
recommended: which is very annoying when you merge a lot of rails. "X" crossovers are part of elemental train track design
hoursPlayed: and leaving it out is completely random and not well thought out.\n- They should have made it easier to make flyovers. Making realistic flyovers is very hard due to the way the bridge pillars are implemented. Tunnels should be easier to make
voteText: too.\n- No way to customize the paint schemes of the trains. Devs say this is for reaslisms sake (while oddly not incorporating any realistic logos)
helpfulPercent: however in real life
votesHelpful: trains have been in different color schemes all the time in different decades (e.g. german trains) or special schemes. The trains are also a random collection of german/swiss/austrian trains
votesTotal: which makes the lack of paint schemes even more weird and unrealistic.\n\nIt just seems to me that the devs didn't really think it through that much. However
votesFunny: despite these shortcomings
commentsCount:
it is still a great game to play. Lets hope that the mods or devs will alleviate these weird shortcomings soon. Some pros:

- It looks great
- Trains are nice (especially steam trains!)
- Runs smoothly for me so far (Retina Macbook Pro

reviewText: The game is a promise. A nice idea getting better at every update. But now that urban games announced they will direct their efforts at a new game, I got a little frustrated. The game starts as a horse carriage simulation at the beginning, because trains in early game are pretty expensive and not cost effective. In the mid game trains become an interesting choice, but the performance drops dramatically. Also the cargo system doesn't make much sense even in the latest patches. I'd provide a positive review if the game was a beta with room for improvement. But because UG said Train Fever is complete and won't get much attention from now on, I wouldn't recommend unless it's an 80% discount sale.

reviewText: Not worth full price for the simple reason that the learning curve is absurd and elements of the ui are completely counter intuitive, and the tutorial system is horrendously inadequate.  Also buggy on anything but a small map even though i have supported hardware and twice the required memory.  At least it autosaves every game year, because otherwise I would have lost alot of effort due to crashes. After 6 hours of frustration, including stopping to try to read various guides, I still could not get a single piece of cargo to be moved properly. Somehow while having improved graphics over the old Railroad Tycoon series, the game play just does not compare.  In every way that Railroad Tycoon worked, Train Fever fails.  While Railroad Tycoon was logical and rather easy to get a grasp on the basic functions, Tran Fever is just pure frustration.  So sad.  I can only be happy that I got this at 90% off.  EDIT - I want to enjoy this game, and I can see how eventually I may be able to once I fully learn how to make the game operate the way it should.  The problem remains that this is an incomplete game because to much is left to the new user to figure out on their own, and you simply can not do it without seeking outside help.  If not for YouTubers creating visual walk trhus of how to make the signals function and how to make cargo routes work, i would have had no concievable idea of how to do it, because the in game guide is completely inadequate, and doing what worked in other comparable games fails completely in this one because logic mechanis are not the same but also not explained by the developers. It was not until watching a Youtube walk thru that I found out how the cargo system actuall works and how routes have to be broken up to get them to function correctly.  Basicly for the common gamer this is still definitely thumbs down, while for train and management simulation enthusiasts it has some potential, but be prepared for hours of frustration before things start to click.

reviewText:
Let's start with cons. I hate the cargo system. First of all, it works on demand, not on supply, which is an economical error. Second of all, it's buggy as hell. Several times happened to me that a cargo line was used for half a year and then it became unused for no reason and would remain unused unless I changed line's options. (Point A to B switched into point B to point A and everything came back to normal for another half of year). This is really irritating since cargo lanes are the main source of money.
The third thing is the variety of vehicles in the game feels really narrow. You start with two trains in XIX century, maybe fifteen trains in XX century and a couple of new ones in XXI century. This many trains should be available in only XIX century at least.
Forth thing is this game is unbalanced. Providing goods to towns is less profitable than providing goods to factories which is totally incorrect. Moreover, on hard mode providing goods to towns with trains is money wasted, because there's no way to make any profit out of it. Some vehicles are highly profitable, while others are just garbage.

Well, about pros. They are still developing this game so hopefully all of this will get sorted out.

reviewText:
Let's start with cons. I hate the cargo system. First of all, it works on demand, not on supply, which is an economical error. Second of all, it's buggy as hell. Several times happened to me that a cargo line was used for half a year and then it became unused for no reason and would remain unused unless I changed line's options. (Point A to B switched into point B to point A and everything came back to normal for another half of year). This is really irritating since cargo lanes are the main source of money.
The third thing is the variety of vehicles in the game feels really narrow. You start with two trains in XIX century, maybe fifteen trains in XX century and a couple of new ones in XXI century. This many trains should be available in only XIX century at least.
Forth thing is this game is unbalanced. Providing goods to towns is less profitable than providing goods to factories which is totally incorrect. Moreover, on hard mode providing goods to towns with trains is money wasted, because there's no way to make any profit out of it. Some vehicles are highly profitable, while others are just garbage.

Well, about pros. They are still developing this game so hopefully all of this will get sorted out.

reviewText: Not worth full price for the simple reason that the learning curve is absurd and elements of the ui are completely counter intuitive, and the tutorial system is horrendously inadequate.  Also buggy on anything but a small map even though i have supported hardware and twice the required memory.  At least it autosaves every game year, because otherwise I would have lost alot of effort due to crashes. After 6 hours of frustration, including stopping to try to read various guides, I still could not get a single piece of cargo to be moved properly. Somehow while having improved graphics over the old Railroad Tycoon series, the game play just does not compare.  In every way that Railroad Tycoon worked, Train Fever fails.  While Railroad Tycoon was logical and rather easy to get a grasp on the basic functions, Tran Fever is just pure frustration.  So sad.  I can only be happy that I got this at 90% off.  EDIT - I want to enjoy this game, and I can see how eventually I may be able to once I fully learn how to make the game operate the way it should.  The problem remains that this is an incomplete game because to much is left to the new user to figure out on their own, and you simply can not do it without seeking outside help.  If not for YouTubers creating visual walk trhus of how to make the signals function and how to make cargo routes work, i would have had no concievable idea of how to do it, because the in game guide is completely inadequate, and doing what worked in other comparable games fails completely in this one because logic mechanis are not the same but also not explained by the developers. It was not until watching a Youtube walk thru that I found out how the cargo system actuall works and how routes have to be broken up to get them to function correctly.  Basicly for the common gamer this is still definitely thumbs down, while for train and management simulation enthusiasts it has some potential, but be prepared for hours of frustration before things start to click.
