reviewText:
TL;DR: Buy on sale, and only on sale

When I first bought this game and played ~3 hours, I was enthralled. This game had reignited a passion for trains (steam trains especially) that I hadn't had since I was 10. The game immersed me in a potent mixture of nostalgia and wonder. I recommended the game based on these feelings.

Another ~5 hours later and the illusion of wonder has worn off. The cracks have begun to show, and now I understand why reviews are mixed. Because the game is essentially a mixed bag - here's why.

My specs I've been playing this on are:
Intel Core i5 @2.5GHz
8GB RAM
Intel HD 4000 Graphics (mobile)

I'm gaming on my subpar school laptop. The game actually doesn't look bad on the lowest settings. Stutters a bit when zoomed completely out and viewing the full map, but as long as I don't zoom out completely, it plays pretty well. Props to the game for that.

Moving on: the gameplay - you build bus routes to ferry your passengers around inside cities, build train stations in these cities to connect cities to each other, and watch as the passengers line up at the station, begging to be allowed onto one of your fancy railroad cars. Add sidings, loops, or even another whole length of track to allow more trains to ferry your passengers between towns. Expand to another town, repeat the process! Dig tunnels and build bridges! (you even get to choose your kind of bridge truss!) Add more cars to your trains and upgrade them as technology advances with time! Cargo trains are much trickier (based on what gameplay I have they seem more like a late-game feature), though they are much more complex than simply connecting passenger lines together. Hook up different industries and resources like coal mines, ore mines, sawmills, and more and connect them to goods manufacturers like oil refineries, lumber yards, and more! Pay off your initial starting loan and make millions! Sounds great, right? Well, it is. What ruins the experience in the long-run is the UI.

The first (and biggest) mistake the game makes is lumping all your bus and RR lines for all cities into ONE management window. Doesn't seem like a big deal, right? Not at first. But it becomes really frustrating later on when I'm trying to see which bus lines correspond to which railroad lines, which ones are running cargo, and why some bus lines are losing money. Every line is numbered. So if I create two bus lines in three different cities, and then connected two of the cities with one RR line, it would look like (ignoring the parenthesis and the words inside parenthesis):
LINE 1 (bus line city 1)
LINE 2 (bus line city 2)
LINE 3 (bus line city 3)
LINE 4 (railroad line for city 1-city 2)
Yes, each line is color-coded, but that doesn't significantly alleviate the problem. Additionally, the way line numbers are listed, it's extremely wonky. Say I have 30 bus and railroad lines. The game will list the lines as follows:
LINE 1
LINE 11
LINE 12
LINE 13
[...]
LINE 19
LINE 2
LINE 20
LINE 21
[...]
LINE 29
LINE 3
LINE 30
THIS IS HOW TRAIN FEVER NUMBERS ITS LINES!!! It becomes a logistical nightmare to manage your trains. Make no mistake, large corporations can be bureaucratic minefields to one degree or another, but Train Fever takes it to an unreasonable level.

The other major part of my beef with this game is the laying of track. Specifically, train stations. So I want to have a passenger station and, the way I was planning it, I was going to have a cargo train directly across from the passenger station. No biggie, right? WRONG, WRONG WRONG!!!
> try to build cargo station directly across from passenger station with tracks in between
> TF hates me
> lay down second line of track and over a road just outside of where planned stations will be
> creates two-line railroad crossing
> still can't build cargo station without the game raging on me
> give up after 45 minutes
> try to delete one of the lines crossing the road
> TF wants me to delete both
> rage
> begrudgingly delete double-RR crossing
> try to lay down new track to reconnect original passenger station
> Unable to place track
> Rage
> delete road
> able to lay track
> try to repave road
> Unable to pave over track, you must build track after paving road
> RAGE

On that note, the game will seemingly at random not want to place track in a given spot or create a split line for whatever reason. It's frustrating when it seems it happens for no good reason.

I bought this over winter sale for 80% off ($6 USD). That's all it's worth.

reviewText:
After finishing the game once or twice and trying out a few of the mods I can say this game currently is not worth buying at full price if you get it at a sale you might feel satisfied.

So what is this game? Well its a railroad tycoon game starting in 1850 where you need to get to the year 2000 without going bankrupt, build railroads, buslines, tramlines, and make a transport empire.

So whats wrong with the game?

Bugs... Bugs everywhere...
Especially after the year 1920 you try to do anything and *Hiccup* It's so unpolished and buggy, its got me into the habbit of saving every 5 minutes wich really takes you out of the game world at times. The music is really out of place, it sorta sounds like a fusion of 50s swing and techno and in the early stages of the game (1850-1900) it really doesn't fit the time period, aswell as this IT GETS IN YOUR HEAD I can't believe how catchy it is, you ut the game down for a couple days and then suddenly you start humming to yourself... and then it never ends...

Despite I found this Incredibly addicting, I found it really hard to put the game down at times even when it did crash or the framerate tanked I rebooted the game and found myself playing for another few hours.

A really good comparison to this game is : Cities Skylines (Paradox Interactive)
The gameplay is incredibly simillar however Cities Skylines hasn't got much depth in the railroad department but invredbile amounts in the city building aspect honestly I'd recomend that game alot more

SO all in all this isn't worth buying but if you see it on sale say 50 - 80% off Id definately pick it up

reviewText:
I had high hopes for this game scratching the RT and TTD itch, but it's just not good enough.

It is a visually very appealing game, it is obvious that a lot of attention has been given to the aesthetic, I imagine that a fully operational transport network would look pretty cool in this set up, but I can't say for sure because I cannot bring myself to get into it. The actual rail simulation part of this game is incredibly simple (no bad thing) but it is betrayed at every turn by a cluster♥♥♥♥ UI, every minor action feels like a tedious effort and the clunky UI does nothing to help you at any stage, the simple act of building a line and getting it running efficiently feels like a chore, which ultimately makes the game unsatisfying as this is the sole purpose of the genre.

I will use the example of getting tandem tracks to operate correctly, rather than the lines neatly following each other side by side you find yourself having to build separate, widely spaced bridges over water just to satisfy the criteria for a valid build.  On top of this there is no simple way to have two, one way tracks running side by side, you have to make it happen manually, a pointless time consuming activity which should be implimented automatically. (which reminds me, points need some work too, you cant have lines pass over other lines without it becoming a junction, making an already difficult to get right aspect of the game even more unsatisfying).

It feels like these things can be fixed if the devs are willing, I want to like this game so I would be pleased to change my review if and when it gets fixed up a bit, until then however keep a hold of your money.

reviewText:
TLDR: while it looks great and has a wide variety of trains to choose from, especially thanks to mods, it is just not a great game and the DEV's are moving on to another game. I mostly played this game earlier, before the US update, but I reinstalled it some time afterwards and gave it another shot. Not that much appears to have changed, which is disappointing, as there are still quite a few things that could be improved. They promise they will keep supporting this one at least for a while, but major updates probably won't be forthcoming. I'm expecting only some bugfixes, not added content or changed mechanics. Such a shame. It is, in many ways, a decent game. There are also various mods which improve the game even further. But it is certainly not a great game. It really showed a lot of promise and might have ended up as a much better game than even Railroad Tycoon or any of its successors, never mind Transport Tycoon. Now my hope for that is fading fast. So not recommended, unless you're a hardcore train fanatic, eager to play anything to do with trains.

Long version: there are many good things about this game. It looks pretty great. It allows you to play with trains and road transport alike. It allows you to build a transport network across a map, connecting various cities and industries, which evolve and grow as you play. New trains and vehicles are unlocked with time. You can play with European or US buildings. It can be a lot of fun to lay out a track and watch your trains, even high speed TGVs, race across them. Unfortunately, the flaws of the game are very distracting.

Track laying is often anything but intuitive. There are a few guides on how to create overpasses and the like, but that kind of thing should be easy to do and it isn't. It often feels as if you're wrestling the game, to try and trick it and get it to do what you want it to do. I've had episodes where the game kept telling me something couldn't be done, or where tunnels ended up coming out just wrong so I had to relay track that then didn't match up, costing me literally millions or whatever coin is used in game, bankrupting my company so I had to restart from a save game. Sometimes I was just trying to lay track alongside of existing track, or turn a single track bridge into a two track bridge and the game just wouldn't cooperate. Why is there no option to lay out track, check if it is the right way, THEN confirm to actually lay the track? How about an undo option? Sometimes you try to lay track and the game things it is easier to carve down a hill, costing you millions, instead of just building a tunnel. Although there is something to be said for the feeling of being victorious when I managed to do something that the game had absolutely refused to cooperate with, even told me repeatedly that it couldn't be done, I highly doubt that any game should be made that way and that people would want to play a game that worked like that.

I also ran into trouble trying to get my trains to pass each other at a crossing. They ended up stopped, again costing me millions before I was able to fix it or forcing me to go back to an earlier save. Just when you think you've laid it out properly, a train stops, for no apparent reason and just turns back, headed the wrong way, all the way to the other side of the map, only losing money in the process. This game really should be able to use signals in a proper and realistic way. But even trying to create proper switches or points (intersections) is next to impossible. When I think I've managed to do exactly what I wanted, they end up confusing my trains so much they just stop altogether or start running on the wrong track. This is a game that tries to appeal to train enthusiasts, the trams and road vehicles seem to be thrown in as an extra, but it doesn't even get the train thing right. All in all, it feels unfinished.

Some things are really still pretty basic. You can't create a map from scratch or adjust the random map in any way. So no placing industries, creating or deleting villages, nothing. Adjusting the settings un such a manner as to make it as flat as possible still results in a map with significant hills, so I can forget playing on a map that even remotely resembles my native country, never mind create an exact replica of an existing area, no matter how small, as the maps are also still pretty small even at the largest settings. The game inclused road vehicles in addition to rail vehicles, but don't include either water or air transport at all. This makes no sense and further limits the opportunities in the game.

Improving or deleting streets is also quite difficult. Some options, like highways, don't even exist. Other options don't work very well, as you quickly end up having to destroy entire buildings, at great expense. In the end, you still end up with gridlock, with no clear way of getting people to get out of their cars, to take public transport. I have a sneaking suspicion that the AI that governs where people want to go is very, very basic and very, very flawed. That makes a game like this pretty much pointless, as instead of a realistic and challenging transport network, you end up having to play along with some obscure rules.

When I played earlier, there were several serious issues, that should not have been allowed to exist in a released game. At one point, I ended up with several corrupted savegames, at another I was completely unable to remove sections of road as they were deemed to be an essential connection, despite them not leading anywhere. I haven't played the current release of the game long enough to be sure, but I haven't encountered them again and am willing to give them the benefit of the doubt and assume both are fixed now. However, it says something about the state the game was in when I bought it and the level of Quality Control that these flaws were in a released game in the first place. So what hope do I have that their next game will be released in a better state? Why would I preorder that one, or buy it at full price, or even at all, based on this experience?

This game comes pretty close to being great however, which makes it all the more sad. With the Developers moving onto another game, there won't be as much support as there was, so all hope of this game being improved to be all that it could ever be, seems lost. It is not terrible, but it is certainly not great. It has something for enthusiasts, but mostly because of how little competition there has been in this field in the past few years. It leaves me feeling disappointed and sad, eager for more. And yet it could have been so much more and seemingly without too much effort. I've seen some interesting suggestions on the community hub and if the publisher changed its mind and came out with a solid update, that would fix the remaining flaws of the game and expand on its possibilities, I might even be persuaded to buy it. Something that I would do with reluctance, as it is still rewarding a company for releasing an unfinished game, but if it was good enough, I'd be willing to set that aside. They have people to feed too and moreover, I really want a game like this, only better. Just a bit better. I get the impression the developers were disappointed too, that they were too ambitious and now want to wash their hands of this game and move onto the real thing. But that would be wrong. Not only because they risk losing the trust of their customers forever, but also because they pass up the opportunity of making something really impressive out of this. They should invest in this game and really build it into a flagship product, show us what they really can do. Then keep releasing expansions. Then move onto the next engine and improve the game even further. They could milk us for years. How is that for a marketing strategy?

reviewText:
This game is a diamond in the rough. It's not perfect, but very enjoyable.

Pros:

+A surprising amount of data is available to you regarding your transit lines.
+Generally nice graphics.
+Cities grow naturally as you expand infrastructure, a la Cities in Motion.
+Two separate campaigns (second one free)


Cons:

-UI is wonky. Windows pop up everywhere, very inconsistently.
-UI needs more scalability.
-Music is awful for the setting, at least in regards to the USA map. Doesn't in any way resemble what I would expect for the old west.



Iffy:

*Campaigns are really just large sandbox maps. Some will love this, some will hate it. Not much in the way of structure.
*Can't speak to how accurate train models are. I've played enough train games to know it's in the ballpark. It's not something that's overly important to me, so beyond that I can't say much.
*It'd be nice if there were more interaction with the cities, a la Railroad Tycoon 3. A little more interaction with industry.
-Tutorial is... less than great. If you don't have a basic grasp of these sort of games, you'll probably be lost.


I know I nitpicked, but I really do enjoy this game. It's Railroad Tycoon meets Cities in Motion. If that sounds like your bag, definitely check it out!

reviewText:
I had high hopes for this game scratching the RT and TTD itch, but it's just not good enough.

It is a visually very appealing game, it is obvious that a lot of attention has been given to the aesthetic, I imagine that a fully operational transport network would look pretty cool in this set up, but I can't say for sure because I cannot bring myself to get into it. The actual rail simulation part of this game is incredibly simple (no bad thing) but it is betrayed at every turn by a cluster♥♥♥♥ UI, every minor action feels like a tedious effort and the clunky UI does nothing to help you at any stage, the simple act of building a line and getting it running efficiently feels like a chore, which ultimately makes the game unsatisfying as this is the sole purpose of the genre.

I will use the example of getting tandem tracks to operate correctly, rather than the lines neatly following each other side by side you find yourself having to build separate, widely spaced bridges over water just to satisfy the criteria for a valid build.  On top of this there is no simple way to have two, one way tracks running side by side, you have to make it happen manually, a pointless time consuming activity which should be implimented automatically. (which reminds me, points need some work too, you cant have lines pass over other lines without it becoming a junction, making an already difficult to get right aspect of the game even more unsatisfying).

It feels like these things can be fixed if the devs are willing, I want to like this game so I would be pleased to change my review if and when it gets fixed up a bit, until then however keep a hold of your money.

reviewText:
TLDR: while it looks great and has a wide variety of trains to choose from, especially thanks to mods, it is just not a great game and the DEV's are moving on to another game. I mostly played this game earlier, before the US update, but I reinstalled it some time afterwards and gave it another shot. Not that much appears to have changed, which is disappointing, as there are still quite a few things that could be improved. They promise they will keep supporting this one at least for a while, but major updates probably won't be forthcoming. I'm expecting only some bugfixes, not added content or changed mechanics. Such a shame. It is, in many ways, a decent game. There are also various mods which improve the game even further. But it is certainly not a great game. It really showed a lot of promise and might have ended up as a much better game than even Railroad Tycoon or any of its successors, never mind Transport Tycoon. Now my hope for that is fading fast. So not recommended, unless you're a hardcore train fanatic, eager to play anything to do with trains.

Long version: there are many good things about this game. It looks pretty great. It allows you to play with trains and road transport alike. It allows you to build a transport network across a map, connecting various cities and industries, which evolve and grow as you play. New trains and vehicles are unlocked with time. You can play with European or US buildings. It can be a lot of fun to lay out a track and watch your trains, even high speed TGVs, race across them. Unfortunately, the flaws of the game are very distracting.

Track laying is often anything but intuitive. There are a few guides on how to create overpasses and the like, but that kind of thing should be easy to do and it isn't. It often feels as if you're wrestling the game, to try and trick it and get it to do what you want it to do. I've had episodes where the game kept telling me something couldn't be done, or where tunnels ended up coming out just wrong so I had to relay track that then didn't match up, costing me literally millions or whatever coin is used in game, bankrupting my company so I had to restart from a save game. Sometimes I was just trying to lay track alongside of existing track, or turn a single track bridge into a two track bridge and the game just wouldn't cooperate. Why is there no option to lay out track, check if it is the right way, THEN confirm to actually lay the track? How about an undo option? Sometimes you try to lay track and the game things it is easier to carve down a hill, costing you millions, instead of just building a tunnel. Although there is something to be said for the feeling of being victorious when I managed to do something that the game had absolutely refused to cooperate with, even told me repeatedly that it couldn't be done, I highly doubt that any game should be made that way and that people would want to play a game that worked like that.

I also ran into trouble trying to get my trains to pass each other at a crossing. They ended up stopped, again costing me millions before I was able to fix it or forcing me to go back to an earlier save. Just when you think you've laid it out properly, a train stops, for no apparent reason and just turns back, headed the wrong way, all the way to the other side of the map, only losing money in the process. This game really should be able to use signals in a proper and realistic way. But even trying to create proper switches or points (intersections) is next to impossible. When I think I've managed to do exactly what I wanted, they end up confusing my trains so much they just stop altogether or start running on the wrong track. This is a game that tries to appeal to train enthusiasts, the trams and road vehicles seem to be thrown in as an extra, but it doesn't even get the train thing right. All in all, it feels unfinished.

Some things are really still pretty basic. You can't create a map from scratch or adjust the random map in any way. So no placing industries, creating or deleting villages, nothing. Adjusting the settings un such a manner as to make it as flat as possible still results in a map with significant hills, so I can forget playing on a map that even remotely resembles my native country, never mind create an exact replica of an existing area, no matter how small, as the maps are also still pretty small even at the largest settings. The game inclused road vehicles in addition to rail vehicles, but don't include either water or air transport at all. This makes no sense and further limits the opportunities in the game.

Improving or deleting streets is also quite difficult. Some options, like highways, don't even exist. Other options don't work very well, as you quickly end up having to destroy entire buildings, at great expense. In the end, you still end up with gridlock, with no clear way of getting people to get out of their cars, to take public transport. I have a sneaking suspicion that the AI that governs where people want to go is very, very basic and very, very flawed. That makes a game like this pretty much pointless, as instead of a realistic and challenging transport network, you end up having to play along with some obscure rules.

When I played earlier, there were several serious issues, that should not have been allowed to exist in a released game. At one point, I ended up with several corrupted savegames, at another I was completely unable to remove sections of road as they were deemed to be an essential connection, despite them not leading anywhere. I haven't played the current release of the game long enough to be sure, but I haven't encountered them again and am willing to give them the benefit of the doubt and assume both are fixed now. However, it says something about the state the game was in when I bought it and the level of Quality Control that these flaws were in a released game in the first place. So what hope do I have that their next game will be released in a better state? Why would I preorder that one, or buy it at full price, or even at all, based on this experience?

This game comes pretty close to being great however, which makes it all the more sad. With the Developers moving onto another game, there won't be as much support as there was, so all hope of this game being improved to be all that it could ever be, seems lost. It is not terrible, but it is certainly not great. It has something for enthusiasts, but mostly because of how little competition there has been in this field in the past few years. It leaves me feeling disappointed and sad, eager for more. And yet it could have been so much more and seemingly without too much effort. I've seen some interesting suggestions on the community hub and if the publisher changed its mind and came out with a solid update, that would fix the remaining flaws of the game and expand on its possibilities, I might even be persuaded to buy it. Something that I would do with reluctance, as it is still rewarding a company for releasing an unfinished game, but if it was good enough, I'd be willing to set that aside. They have people to feed too and moreover, I really want a game like this, only better. Just a bit better. I get the impression the developers were disappointed too, that they were too ambitious and now want to wash their hands of this game and move onto the real thing. But that would be wrong. Not only because they risk losing the trust of their customers forever, but also because they pass up the opportunity of making something really impressive out of this. They should invest in this game and really build it into a flagship product, show us what they really can do. Then keep releasing expansions. Then move onto the next engine and improve the game even further. They could milk us for years. How is that for a marketing strategy?

reviewText:
Now I'm a fan of the Railroad Tycoon franchise and OpenTTD and I was really looking forward to enjoying this game.

The first experience was horrible. The text was all fuzzy and barely readable on a Win10 4k resolution. That problem went away after I restarted the game, however the mouse pointer was restricted to 3/4 of the screen. Lowering the resolution at that point didn't fix it, playing in a window did.

The game lacks a tutorial. It lacks a campain. You're just thrown in the game on your own. It's unbelievable how unpolished the UI is in this game. It really feels like splatted buttons and text by a novice.
Laying rail track is a pain. Raising a road to create a bridge over rail tracks is easy, but that is a whole different ball game for rail bridges over roads. Go figure.

I kept going though, looking at guides and reading forums. But I immediately stopped playing and asked for a refund when I realized that every time the game was computing the finances and displaying the maintenance cost for 3 !!! running vehicles froze the game for a fraction of a second on a 6 core I7 and a 980TI. I'm a software developer and I immediately understood that the simulation is running on a single thread. If this was happening in the first hour of playing the game, imagine what it would be like later on in the game.
UPDATE: Digging into the forums, this is indeed one of the top complaints: http://www.train-fever.com/forums/topic/req-multithreading-performance-issu-large-map/
It becomes unplayable later on in the game or on a large map.

Don't believe the excuse that synchronizing resource access in a multi-threaded app is killing its performance. If the code is done right, and the synchronization primitives are being used correctly, you'll get a cool working game with nicely balanced work loads on all the available CPU cores and even on the GPU compute cores. If things get too hectic and the load reaches a high threshold value, the code can simply lower the simulation speed or coarse grain the steps in order to compensate, but still run tasks in parallel. Nowadays, there is no excuse for not fully taming the power we've got in our computers. Multi-core CPUs weren't invented yesterday!

The graphics are nice, that's the only positive about the game. The developers simply stopped short of finishing the game and moved on to DLCs and future titles. Or I could give them the benefit of the doubt and say that they lacked the skill. Simulations are not easy to get right.

reviewText:
I'm afraid that I cannot recommend this game after several hours of playing it.

There are some positives, and one massive negative (which I'll get to in a minute):
+ The line layout is simple and intuitive, it actually does work pretty well... by and large. There are a couple of oddities here and there (particularly if you've got stations on both sides of a road, for instance) but these are easily resolved.
+ The individual track laying mechanism is a great idea. However, it does come with quite a few caveats.
+ Gameplay is pretty straightforward, you gotta get things from point A to point B, but be prepared as you may lose money at first.

And now... the big negative:

The amount of time that I have spent getting frustrated with trying to build rail bridges over roads is getting ridiculous. I've pretty much given up on the game because the editor is a pain in the butt to work with.

Thought process as follows goes:
Ooh

this looks like a good place to cross over the road. It's perfectly straight and there's plenty of room to do it!"

But then...

NOPE. Can't do it. Nope

reviewText:
This game feels like an early access game even though it is stated not to be one.

It is definitely NOT worth the 25 euro's they are asking for it. It is an unfinished at best and unplayable at worst game. It has some gamebreaking bugs that make this game a chore rather than a pleasure to play.

For starters, I had troubles even getting the game to work. The store page states that I need a GFX card with half the power my system has to run this game. Even so I had frequent stutters and a LOT of crashes. I spent hours trying to fix this game. The forums are littered with complaints about crashes, many of which have not had any answer whatsoever by the devs.

Eventually I seem to have found some sort of half-arsed solution (since apparently in all cases it's the systems fault NOT the game, when it crashes) which causes my game to only sometimes crash.

Now that I have got my game running (kinda) I face all the other issues:

1. Laying train tracks and stations is tedious beyond comprehension. If you can even find a way to place a track, don't think about removing it and placing it again, because it changes the landscape permanently. Yes you can fix this with the landscape tool, but why would I need to?

2. Placing lines seems to work fine at first but is then met with many complications. Oftentimes resulting in trains not moving at all. There are workarounds for this, but they require manual interference rather than the AI just being clever enough to figure things out themselves. This should be something that works intuitively, but rather than that, it require hours of finetuning just to get 1 train track to run half-decent.

3. The game has massive framerate issues. As stated before I ran this game on a card with more than enough power. I set all the settings to the lowest possible. I lowered the resolution and STILL I had frequent drops in framerate. Once again I went to the forums to check if there was a solution and once again I was met with You need to update your system" rather than "Our game is not optimised properly".

Overall this game just feels very sub-optimal. The way you would expect an early access game to feel. If I were to play this

reviewText:
This game is frustrating beyond belief! I was a hardcore OpenTTD and CIM2 & 1 player and managed to achieve massive and functional cities but this?! This thing right here is just plainly stupid. It tries to wow you with nice graphics and at first you might fall for how great it looks but you just wait for this bug fest! Btw. this is my first ever hate comment and first game ever to make me so angry. I really tried to overcome countless amount of problems but it's just impossible.

First of all UI is just terrible. Windows can't be resized, they pop up in random places (sometimes beyond your screen), buttons are tiny, everything requires loads clicking especially if you manage to grow your corporation to a decent size. Developers recently added auto renew option to your lines. Great. It doesn't change the fact that you still have to manually click on every line and chose which car/train you want to use as your new vehicle. What if a new model is researched? Well, repeat that whole process. Is it really that difficult to think and allow to select many lines rather than just one and make batch changes to them?

Other UI problems include little things like the fact that when changing a name of your line you have to always press and hold backspace to delete a default line 1" name. You can't select what you've written
recommended:
you can't move your cursor. Basically you can't do anything that Notepad application can. Little things but wait until you have 100s lines and want to do some simple cleanup.

Bigger errors include things like a lack of save menu! I mean this is just ridiculous. When saving you have to type your name and that's it. You can't select a previous save so if you make one spelling mistake you will create a new save file or what's worse you can easily ovewrite a different game. You can't load a game from any other screen but main menu and all auto save files are mixed with your regular ones so it's just a massive cluster ♥♥♥♥.

Enough about a terrible UX. How about the game itself? I said already that it looks great but that's about it. There is absolutely no AI. ZERO! Your vehicles will move along set paths and that's it. It doesn't matter that there might be other vehicles blocking it
hoursPlayed: if it's stuck it will be stuck forever and you won't know because obviously there is nothing that would inform you.\n\nYour trains will always stop on the same platforms. There is no point in building big train stations because computer will always use the same place to load and unload which is totally ridiculous as there might be 5 billion trains waiting in line to one platform while there are 7 other available. You might think that maybe I need to build signals? I tried. I really tried but this game only has 2 and all they do is let or stop a train. They won't direct to a different track
voteText: they won't do anything useful. You need to have them so your silly train drivers won't crash into one another but you can't use them for anything useful. Just bloody terrible!\n\nBuilding roads and tracks is just totally unbelievably idiotic. Route finder will prefer to build massive
helpfulPercent: stupidly high bridges or long tunnels and claim that it's cheaper that just laying a road on a hill. You also have to lay paths in separate segments and seems like height is applied to a whole section so you end up with these ridiculous lines that costs a fortune and totally wrecks surroundings because computer seems to mix uber high bridges with total destruction of nature. Same with depots and other structures (not that there is many of them). If you put one down on a slight hill
votesHelpful: you won't get a gradual terrain alignment
votesTotal:
you'll get a fricking cliff in the middle of a city that looks weird as hell.

But the worst of it all is cargo. First of all there are only 4 types which you can increase with mods but that doesn't change the fact that factories doesn't follow any rules at all. They sometimes won't produce anything while suggesting that you can increase manufacture by shipping more of the produce. How am I supposed to increase sending of ZERO??!! Then they'll say that line is in no use even if city is accepting resources and all of them are properly connected.

That's actually another thing. There is no explanation to how all of these things work. No tutorial no nothing. If there was a wiki made by developers that would in depth describe the engine of this game maybe you could understand why certain things are happening but at this point it's just a massive lottery. Loads people are speculating on the internet and share their experiments but no one knows for sure. For example there is apparently a 20 minutes limit on waiting time for a cargo to be picked up but I only know this from players that observed such behavior.

You don't know how population is transferring

reviewText:
This game looks clearly unfinished. There are trains but not much fever :)

PROS:
Nice visuals, especially when it comes to the terrain. Railway cuttings and embankments look very realistic. Individual people also change their attire as time passes by, which is an interesting touch.
Modding support, allowing the users to download additional game content.
An American DLC (Free) allowing you to run the simulation in the different environment.
The game is very stable and can happily run in the background as you strive to do more important things on your PC :)
CONS:
Building multiple tracks or a station throat is a nightmare. Modernizing the track layout is next to impossible.
You cannot rebuild a station - add a new platform, goods yard, extend the platform length. Once you want to do so, you need to demolish the existing building and make space for your next one - which includes bulldozing a lot more. Occasionally, the bulldozed space is immediately filled by a new structure, forcing you to repeat the operation again.
You cannot build railway crosssings other than laying track across the road. You are not allowed to build a street crossing an existing track. And should you prefer to build an overbridge instead, you will need a lot more space to run your street above the tracks.
Modding support is... well, flawed.  I needed to reinstall the game and the TF Game Manager (mod manager) after the latter had crashed, rendering my installed mods invisible and thus unable to be enabled (sic!) for my current game. Mods are not used automatically - must be enabled first, then selected when starting (or loading) a game.
Strange selection of trains. In the vanilla game there are only 14 locomotives available for the entire game period, and only 4 of these are available for the 50 years of 19th century. One needs to wait until 1902 to see an engine attaining 100kph speed. Well, I believe that GWR's City Of Truro did 102,3 MPH (that's 165 kph) in 1904, and a lot of British trains had their running speeds in the range of 100 kph well before the turn of the centuries. The LNER A4 Mallard is a curiosity since there is no other British railway vehicle (and only two other non-German/Swiss). No Patentees, no French Cramptons, no French Atlantics or Pacifics, no DRG Einheitslokomotiven, no TEEs. No Shinkansens. Again, this may be corrected by modding, but... see above.
Intermodal passenger transport does not work. Once you place the station in the city, other passenger transport in this city is rendered unnecessary - somehow all the citizens immediately want to travel to other cities and will go by foot to your station, avoiding any connected bus/tram line. It seems that building the intercity connection changes the behaviour of citizens to look for their work/leisure targets somewhere else than their home city.
The game is essentially eventless - once you build your intercity connection, money starts flowing in and that's all. No competition, no breakdowns, no crashes, almost no interaction required other than occasionally replacing the ageing vehicle.
No proper savegame screen. You must specify a filename when saving, and there is no warning if you overwrite any previous file of that name.
Resource hungry. My 3rd Gen i5 laptop with 8GB RAM and 1GB GT525 is barely able to run the game full screen; with full details I achieve single fps. The same laptop can run Arma II, The Bureau: XCOM Declassified and Ultimate General Gettysburg on recommended settings with no trouble.
The game may appeal to German railway fans (or maybe Swiss railway fans), of which I am neither. With the American DLC, it may also appear to American railroad fans, again not to myself. Since the developers are updating the game, perhaps some of the mentioned problems may be fixed. But currently at the standard Steam selling price, it seems grossly overpriced.

reviewText:
don't bother

i want to really like this game because it fills the gaps that made railroad tycoon just plain silly. e.g. proper grading, realistic looking tracks and trains. it's a more realistic approach to railroad tycoon. that is where it ends. the interface sucks. it gets very slow by the year 1990. i have most of the map full of bus, train, and tram routes.

now we're presented with the double standard of living, people want faster routes or to drive cars instead, similar to real life, excellent right? the problem is, the road system is very lacking in that traffic jams up very easily, then guess what happens: all your bus and tram route times are slowed by a lot, making them even less desirable, and causing even more traffic! don't use tram or busses you say? get bent :P

furthermore, you end up upgrading the entire road infrastructure yourself. in the cities, many of the roads can't be upgraded to 4 lanes because the computer built all the structures around it, collision errors, etc..

building tracks is painful. even after building a ton of train lines, i still have to fiddle around way too much, to either make proper grading or solve 'terrain' issues. trains can also get stuck indefinitely if you are not careful.. you'll see.

the graphics aren't superb either, other than zooming down to city streets, it's a rather drab landscape that doesn't feel alive.

it's a very good attempt, but this is not ready for primetime. replacing the game engine is probably a good start

reviewText:
Perhaps now that this game is officially abandonware my review won't get downvoted by frosty-eyed shills.

I deleted my first review because some time after I posted it I presumed it would be long out of date. Unfortunately the game remains unfinished, now officially abandoned, with many important features for creating a network such as simple crossovers are left out, many promised features abandoned such as content expansions along with further support for a game that is still pretty broken. The engine seems to have been unfinished or unsuitable from the start, an inability to cross roads over rail is something which apparently can't be fixed. The building system is frustrating, the game is feature lite, the whole experience has been frustrating.

I wanted to like this game, much of my play time is idle time spent minimised while I while away frustration in order to give the game more chances. Maybe buy this game on sale for a fiver if you really want to ♥♥♥♥♥ out playing trains and you keep wishing there was something more modern than Railroad Tycoon or OTTD. DO NOT get burned for full price like I was foolish enough to be.

Having bought this program on Steam I struggled to get it to work correctly on my Mac Book Pro - Lion Operating system  - After 6 hours of sheer frustration in which I found it impossible to have any control over navigating across the maps which accompany the game I finally gave up. Steam has subsequently turned down my request for a refund I am appealing, so be warned. I will now be taking up this issue with Visa.

reviewText:
I was excited to see a new entry in the train econ simulater genre, unfortunately what we got was a half finished game.

The game performs terribly, very slow and stuttering.  Construction of lines is fussy, with constant complaints of obstructions and missed connections.  It is certainly not as smooth and simple as the demo videos show.  Navigating the 3D landscape is frustratingly slow and laborious, no overview map to see the land.  Lots of scrolling in and out.   When you scroll out you cannot be close enough to the terrain to edit, but when you scroll in you cannot see where you are going to build your lines.

The game is basically a 3D copy of Transport Tycoon.  Taking the worst aspects of Transport Tycoon and combining them with the annoying 3D interface of Railroads!.  The game suffers from billions of pop up windows, just like transport tycoon.  The interface looks unpolished and poorly thought out.  Add to that the difficulty of interfacing with a 3D world and the limitations that full 3D puts on map sizes and you have a dissapointment.   If you are looking to build continent spanning empires, go grab the original Railroad Tycoon series and skip this.  The game lacks any story line and is simply an impersonal generated map, with no specific goals, needs or other driving factors.

Overall it feels unfinished, unpolished.  Like a game engine without a game behind it.

reviewText:
-- addition to review --
We just had the multithreading patch, the game has seen some improvements for sure. But IMHO, the core problems from my initial review still exist. And even though gridlocks have been noticable patched, they havent been fixed. They are still there, just less.

Graphics/Sound is all good. Simulation has its problem and illogical parts, which can become problematic at times.

-- original review --
I would have to say it was worth my money considering how many hours I have spent on it, on the other hand the value of that time was taken down drastically by the problems the game has on a simulation level and with its tools. And considering this game has little to no value for a quick 3h game, but is meant to played for many hours I would have to say it isn't worth it as once you reach a level where it starts to get interesting the nuissances become problems. Graphics/Sound/Music was fine. But the core of the game, its simulation is just bad.

Not to badmouth the game, cuz they could still fix things, but to support my negative review here goes a list of things I have encountered: Laying down roads or rails often results in collision" without clearly specifying what is colliding leaving the user to guess what to demolish. Using the "Load All" option can actually cause your line to be ignored completely. The amount of traffic that buildings generate can bring the traffic in the city to a grinding halt

reviewText:
A word of warning:

If you want to build a large railroad network, something on a national scale, this game is not what you want.

The largest map possible has a grid of 5x5 cities. So if you start in the center and build tracks to the next two cities in any direction you will hit the end of the map. And I was told by some guys from the community that they play on maps with 5 towns because everything above that is killed by performance issues.

So, only buy it if you are into micro-managing trains with signals and all of that, but don't buy it if you want the large scale tycoon thing.

reviewText:
What this game does well; everything looks pretty, lay some very nice realistic track, train modeling and detail is excellent, realistic cargo and passenger movement

What this game lacks?  Everything that makes a good transport building game fun.   There is no competitive element whatsoever.  No AI and no multiplay compability,  No way to measure yourself against something.  This is a game of survival.  It is impossible to make money at anything besides passenger transport.   It's very difficult to make money running industry in this game.  The cost to maintain your vehicle is outrageous compared to how make it will make on a run. Supply seems to be dictated by how frequent the trains/buses stop at the station.  There seems to be no limit to the loan you can take out ( maybe i just never reached it, but when your 50ish mil in debt it's time to startover )

I think this game is suppose to appeal to people that build scale model train sets.  Because that is basically what this is, a game that lets you make very detail and visually appealing track sets.  The towns grow around your track and it's all very cool,  just not that fun.

oh and it may be called train fever but if you build trains to start you are almost doomed to go broke right away....

reviewText: I do like a few things about this game.  I like that the main mechanic is people and industry will only use your services if you are faster than just walking. It's easy to setup bus routes, and trucking routes and turn a proffit.  The trains on the other hand rarely turn a proffit, they are just to expensive to be useful.  Also, the laying of track is so tedius that it takes a lot of the fun out of setting up a rail line.  I was hoping for more of an updated OpenTTD with easier to understand mechanics. reviewText:
I came into this wanting a train game where I could set up routes and make money to get new trains and routes, just a basic train tycoon sort of experience. That's pretty much what this game offers, but only at a very shallow level. I'm sad to say it didn't live up to my expectations at all.

As a train set it is extremely limited in what you can do and requires extensive time to unlock any eras or vehicles at all to play with. There is no competitive element. So, just what is compelling here?

Most of it felt to me very incomplete and broken, with very poor feedback on what systems are doing under the hood and therefore little way to make sense of its failings. Often things just won't work for no reason. It's hard for me to rationalize why this game can't measure up in a fairly dead / abandoned genre, as it seems to have plenty of good ideas and then nothing at all to hold them together. If this were an early access alpha I would call it promising.

Instead I'm surprised that this game came out last year and it still hasn't been patched so that track and road laying were not so cumbersome, limited, and fails so often. I can't think of any problems mentioned in Rock Paper Shotgun's review that have actually been taken care of, and it's been a long time and many patches since so just what is happening here where a game is released with serious, unintentional flaws and just keeps them?

You'd be better off with Sid Meier's Railroads! or for a single-player transport tycoon experience maybe Cities in Motion 2. This game just feels extremely unfinished and I feel really betrayed that they made me pay 35$ for it. You'd think a 65% user rating would mean something but the rating system has really failed here. I don't know what people are expecting, thign thing is probably way better than Cities XXL and some shovelware tycoon game, but compare it to games that came out in 2006 and it's a real disappointment.

reviewText:
I want to love this game,but I just cannot. For those of you who are debating about if you want this game or not,read this review,and decide from there. Basically,this games is like a modern day Locomotion or Transport Tycoon,only not as good. Like,at ALL. The game does have redeemable factors,but all the bad things just completely drown them out.

Pros:

-Good Music: I have to say,the music is catchy and is very Tycoon game-ish.
-Decent Graphics: Not the prettiest,but not the most ugly either.

Cons:

-No Objectives:In games like Locomotion,you played on many different maps each with a unique objective (transport a certain amount of goods,reach a certain company rating,etc.) In Train Fever,however,there is no goal in sight other than Don't go bankrupt!" which is the barebone objective of tycoon games.

-No Rival A.I:No competing companies

reviewText: While this was fun for the first few hours. As soon as you connect all cities, there isn't much else to do. Yeah you get updated rails later in the game and you can task your self with updating the infrastructure but other than that the game becomes very empty after connecting every city. No AI to compete against, hell there isn't much to compete against at all except running out of money. Laying rail ways can work, then not work at all. I tried getting my self to play this game as a relaxing way to waste time on the weekend but, it just feels empty after a while and becomes not fun to play at all. Its a good attempt at filling the void of where Rail Road Tycoon 3 left off but, there isn't much to do after you connected every city. Except start a new game before running into the same problem.

reviewText:
The game concept is great as is the graphics, though everything is ruined by implementation. Here's major reasons why you'll be disappointed:
1. Crazy controls. I mean it. You build double track train line and want to place one way signals along the way, how many clicks this action deserve? 3 clicks for each signal! You want to replace your aging truck fleet? Great, you can seen all of them to depot, but then you need to buy them one by one, assign to line and space them evenly, or they will roam in crowd for their lifetime. Thats just couple of examples, user experience is totally appailing.
2. Supply-demand system, It is unbalanced. You can build your 1M$ line + 500K$ train from the oil wells to refinery only to see that wells only produce 1 unit of oil/year, even if the refinery is connected to towns striving for 'goods' (you see, oil well->refinery->town - thats really long production chain), The only way to assess future production is to check whether the industries send their goods on foot by the roads (on my maps its 1/10 of all industries, others lie dormant with 0 production).
3. Game spans from 1850 till 2020 and you get only a few engine models. That's could be partialy solved by mods.

reviewText:
Too early to buy! DO NOT WASTE MONEY!
Game looks like alpha or early beta.
In comparison with Transport Tycoon, but better only graphics, the rest of the game much worse.
There are no multiplayer
There are no AI competitors
Industry chains too short - 2 step, for example: wood -> goods or oil -> goods.
There are only 3 chains: 4 row materials and only 3  manufactures
game interface is squalor: looks like black on white simple HTML without CSS (ingame windows), some buttons looks like simple text not like a button (start/stop train button for example)
Building railways only by short pieces like on video, if you try longer ones, then game greatly slows down up to slideshow and does not depend on the graphics settings (game runs smoothly on maximum settings except this moments)
Manufactures works from game to game differently. One time its works good, and after new game start all manufactures produce maximum 1 piece of resource per year (is it bug or feature?)
If you want to buy new vehicle (bus, lorry, tram) to the existing route, you can't just copy existing one - no such option, do it manually
no autoreplace to outdated vihicles, so it becomes a nightmare to manually replace them (there are no copy function, see above)
if vehicle was sent to depot it loses route, you need set it manually to send vehicle back
route names are: Line1, Line2 and etc. With many routes you have a problem to remember all.
Sorting in route list looks funny:
Line1,
Line10,
Line11,
......
Line2,
Line21,
etc
game have no icon on windows taskbar (LOL)
lights / semaphores  are primitive and does not allow to build ways with heavy traffic like in Transport Tycoon
buildings (except crane), manufactures, semaphores have no animationthis list can be continued, but i'm tired... and very disappointed :(

reviewText:
Sadly this was one of the titles I was excited over coming out, but for its price it is beaten by the old dogs in the railroad / transport tycoon games.
In fact, Railroad Tycoon 2 with its shortcomings will actually excite you more, and is more intutive than this game.
That is the game's first downfall, lack of tutorials, or rather a cheapskate way of doing it.
The tutorials in game are JUST a sloppy redirect link to the Steam guides for this game, the public directory of Steam guides at that with lackluster content.
It works, but the instability of the Steam system will easily give you headaches on some days, and leaving you with ZERO tutorials, or forced to watch a 10 minute video to find out how to rotate a building or station.

Which leads us into another problem, zero keybinds, you dislike the rotation of buildings on the N and M key? Tough luck, that is set in stone and CAN'T be changed in the options.

Another problem I have noticed is that the audio tends to go wonky and skips during gameplay, this especially evident with the gameplay music if you are opening menu's or the like, and it isn't a lack of performance / FPS, as the game runs nicely elsewhere when scrolling and zooming, but opening and closing menu's triggers it, and may be a symptom of much bigger problems underneath the surface.

In short, do I recommend you buy this game? Well it is a refreshing breath into the transport genre, but their competitors who only had the problem of being old, with poor 2D or DirectX 6 or DirectX 7 graphics, will  kick this game hard when it comes gameplay.
OpenTTD is a serious contender to this game, and is also under constant evolution, and while it is hard to beat, the devs better shape up and get their act together.

EDIT: As a quick update to the latest set of updates rolled out at 22nd of May 2015, the issues STILL stand, except now you can hear the music problem even just idling in the main menu.
Steam guides are still used, and Steam is STILL unreliable with frequent downtimes, and the keybinds still cannot be changed.

reviewText:
After 140 hours of gameplay, not recommended.  It is a very boring game.

Do not believe the minimum specs listed - not even close to accurate.
Graphics are poor - dull, drab and lacking crispness.
Railway operations are too simplistic and do not work like a real railway operations. (when I saw steam engines running at speed pumping out black smoke I should have realised then that that the devs probably did not know much about trains)
Many bugs still to be fixed.
Signals are invisible except on max zoom level.
Track laying is a pain even when it decides to behave correctly.
The industry/goods side of things is very weak.
Game maps tend to be repetitive.  Played one map then you've played them all.

And the showstopper - there are too few trains.  One train will usually be enough to service an entire line connecting 5 or 6 towns.  In the 20 or so games I have played the most trains I have had running is 5.  The game becomes one where you watch 1 or 2 trains run back and forward over a featureless landscape, then upgrade them when a new engine becomes available, and then sit there and watch the 2 trains run back and forward over a featureless landscape, ........  It's like a record playing the same song again and again.

There is no incentive to build long lines as exist in the real world because no-one wants to go anywhere far away.  There is a 20 minute rule where the population won't travel at all if the entire trip is longer than 20 minutes (which equates to the next train stop usually).  This is possibly a result of modelling passengers individually.  Each boid chews up cpu and so the game has been dumbed down to minimise the number of boids but maximise the number of boid trips by making maximum trip length quite short.  End result is that the game just doesn't feel like a real railway.

reviewText:
I very much wanted to like this game. I have over 85 gaming titles, including other" train sims. Many have incredible graphic emersion and I set them all to the highest resolution available. These games run smooth and with solid framerates. (none of them required me to "tinker" with the graphic card or any aspect of my computer to run at capasity)

So when I looked at this game I saw that the graphics were not of the same caliber I assumed that running the game would be a breeze for my computer. Wow.. was I wrong.

I loaded my first game (Medium map)  and once it loaded I was beside myself at the lag that was present. I thought.. this cant be right... So I tried to dumb down the graphic settings to see if it helped. No change..

System Specs:

I7 3.00 on an X58 motherboard.
24 gig of ram
Nvidia GTX 580 (2 gig Vram)
Win 7 pro

Even with this level of system resourses the lag spikes make this game unplayable.
And I don't understand it. I run Skyrim at full settings
recommended:
Crysis 3 at full settings. and all of them are high end graphical miracles that emerse you into new and amazing worlds.  Train Fever although fun looking does not even come close to delivering this experience. Its a map with roads and rails crossing over them. You dont even get a "ride / follow the train" view.

How can a simplistic looking map game harsh my system so bad?

Clearly there is something wrong with the game. And I will NOT tinker with my system to make this game work at the risk of making my computer unable to run the other games.
When someone buys a new game. they should not have to jump hoops to make it work. The developers need to sort it out within the code. To do anything less will only limit your market share. Not everyone knows how to tinker with system settings.

I am very disapointed with Train Fever and I have no choice but to shelve it as an "unplayable game" and move on to another game. I cannot recommend this to anyone and I caution those that are considering buying it.. You WILL be disapointed with the frame rate."

reviewText: This game works and I do actually like it but I don't recommend it at this time because it is not finished. There is so much stuff missing that should have been included on release that it is not worth the £20 price tag. The TF forums are flooded with suggestions of what players would like to see included in the game but they are suggesting basic stuff that should already have been included. Modders (god bless 'em) are already hard at work doing the dev's job for them... for free. A minimum 50% reduction in price and I wouldn't have a problem recommending TF as a good purchase with amazing potential.\nHaving said that... 6 days after launch and I still cannot play TF unless I disable my AVG security. reviewText:
Great game in concept but needs some fixing on the train front.
Overall a great game, but some of the points below will need fixing before I turn it back on personally,
Good Points;
1. Graphics are stunning.
2. Large world.
3. People are dynamic
4. Great choice of vehicles available.

Bad Points;
1. If you have built a decent train line using the track you get in 1850, you will spend hours later in the game removing all of the track, and then replacing it with high speed/electric in exactly the same place! Please put in a feature to upgrade the whole line with either the same way the roads can be upgraded!
2. Being able to lay two way track (and switches) would be a massive help.
3. There is no ability to create road/track, and then commit all at once, this means that if you make a mistake, you have to rip it all up and try again.
4. Creating bridges and tunnels are difficult to plan.

Couple of bits I've not seen mentioned that may improve the game.
1. I would like to be able to choose which platform my route uses.
2. Waypoints would be useful, so that I could pass a fast train seperately to the once on the normal line.
3. I modded a few of the waggons to give me specialised cargo capacity, ie only wood, only iron etc.
4. It is way to easy to make money with the lorries, as they can carry equal amounts of everything, maybe they should also be more specialised...

reviewText:
Probably the first thing you are going to try with this game is putting up couple of stations and laying the tracks. Inserting stations is quite straight forward but when you try to connect those with tracks, the agony...
Let me explain little bit more detailed. In principle it is straight forward, you select track and drag it from point A to point B. When you start dragging the line it tries to keep it levelled at all costs, literally. So what I did to keep costs lower, adjust it by the contours. This would even by itself sound tedious, but it's not what made me stop playing.  It was that once I tried to cope with contours the track wouldn't get levelled again. It was raising at steady pace. I couldn't get it to lower at all, raising on the other hand was possibility.
Have they tried playing this game before publishing or did they just wish for the best?
The game has good concept but at it's current state I wouldn't suggest it to anyone. If they fix the bugs I might even get to core part of this game, but now I'm too irritated to try.

reviewText:
Oh dear. Where do I start. This game has (or rather had) so much potential. Just a remake of Transport Tycoon would have  been enough for most fans. But its just a bad game. Here it goes:

- lackluster interface that looks like something you can program in VisualBasic with smallish numbers and UI elements
- no AI
- weird size ratios between stations and town buildings. Some bus stations are huge compared to the town size
- very little economic gameplay, don't expect RR2 levels of management here (on par with TTD though)
- no area indicator for stations (really not funny if you want to build bus/ tram lines)
- you can't start later than 1850 until you get the achievements. You start out with a horse buggy. Its called TRAIN Fever. TRAINS!!
- very unintuitive cargo system, industry buildings are relly small sizewise compared to trains and stations, looks just weird.

Here comes the most annoying aspect: Building tracks:

Building tracks is similar to RR2 but it does not work out. There are constantly farms. buildings or really small roads in the way. Sometimes it says not enough space. The tool permanently builds cuts or embankments. The whole track looks juist ugly with those. Worst of all you have to build your track in small segments. And don't get me started on double tracks.

The problem ist that sometimes you realize that the planned route will not work out (gradients are not well shown on the map) and you need to plan an alternative route. Well, your money is gone...you CAN NOT PLAN your route. How could they not add a route planner for this game. I wasted so much money trying to build track (and buying this game).

Stick with OpenTTD. It looks dated but the mechanics are solid.

reviewText:
I've been a huge fan of tycoon games - particularly transportation tycoon games for a really long time. I've been looking forward to Train Fever since I first heard about it. Unfortunately, it has proved to be probably my most disappointing game purchase this year.

I think my big issue with Train Fever is that it is just not quantitatively fun. It feels like you are wrestling with the track editor in order to build anything. The challenge isn't identifying where to lay track in order to maximize a profit, but simply in building the infrastructure. A prospect like building a junction between two pairs of lines is almost nightmarish in complexity and difficulty to execute.

I've concluded that the developers are huge fans of trains, to the expense of actual gameplay. Things like the actual trains are rendered impressively well, with little things like the coupling rods on the wheels working perfectly. Unfortunately, trains won't route to spread load between multiple lines on a station. You can't lay road across railway lines - it has to be the other way around. You can't do something as simple as have an intersection between two lines without them connecting.

The game also lacks anything in the way of charm. The music is not particularly good, and gets repetitive very quickly. The cities and industries feel very lifeless. I compare it to the (admittedly flawed) Railroad Tycoon 4 which used music and graphics to evoke the nostalgia of steam era trains.

Could it still become a good game? Possibly, but I doubt it. It feels like it should be in early access, and it feels unfinished. It feels like effort was put into the game, but that gameplay is secondary to just making cool looking trains.

Should it be at the $30 price point? Not at this stage.

reviewText: I have several different train simulators and games at this point and this is pretty much the worst of them. The in-game help is horrible, disconnected, and basically doesn't get you up and running". As others have noted
date: it's trying to jam too much into one game so it feels very half-butted rather than doing one or two things whole-butted. The panning and scrolling are jerky and feel very "shareware" like. The graphics are pretty rudimentary. For example
recommended: when creating a tunnel you get an angled mess that looks like a bottomless quick sand pit rather than a nice entrance and exit to the tunnel. Even the main menu looks like a major accident when you change to higher resolutions. Errors are even funnier! You'll get errors like "Not enough space" when you're trying to connect a road to a station...in the middle of a pasture! Or "Collision! Terrain alignment collision. Not enough space" What the heck does THAT mean?\n\nWhen you're building a track
hoursPlayed:
to scroll the landscape you have to continue holding down the left mouse button to lay track while at the same time holding down the right mouse button and moving the mouse in the opposite direction to scroll the screen. Really? Did anyone teach these developers how to write software? When laying track it automatically curves when you want to go straight...and then you get another error messages that have more meaning in a C++ compiler than in a train simulation game. It seems like the designers got into a room and decided on the following tenets:

1. Make the help as useless as possible.
2. Make the error messages even more useless than the help.
3. Make the controls for the UI as useless as the error messages.
4. Make the graphics look as close as possible to Pac Man.
5. Make the game extremely unintuitive to chase potential customers away so that we can go bankrupt.
6. Charge a lot of money so we came make as much as possible before declaring baankruptcy.

This wasn't worth the money it cost me

reviewText:
Back in the day I played a Magazine Demo of Transport Tycoon (TT) and was hooked. I then went to town and bought the only copy I had remember seeing for sale for a full £30, but it was £30 well spent as it is probably the game I have played the most over the years.

Train Fever is a blatant rip-off of the concepts of TT, but is missing quite a few features that were in the original TT, so might be considered Transport Tycoon Lite with better graphics. It is however also missing gameplay aspects which means this game is not very enjoyable. While TT was quite basic I think Train Fever needs a few more features (and perhaps a few unique ones not copied from TT!) to make it less basic.

The aim of TT was not really about making money, as once you got past a certain point you would be earning enough to do mostly anything, and spend time refining and increase train lines on routes needing more demand and the upgrade them to Monorail and then Maglev and Subsidies at the start which paid more and would help you get the money rolling in.

Subsidies are not included in Train Fever and it only seems to have road vehicles and trains, where TT also had ships and aircraft although this game also does not have any water, so ships will not be possible. Expect to just create a few train lines and then hit high speed and wait until they start making money to be able to create more.

Other things missing from this game is competition where TT had computer opponents, even though their intelligence was not always great. Train Fever seems a bit empty and lonely as you are the only transport company in the game.

The graphics are nice but the playability just ain't there for me. The railines I have created have all been curvy to avoid mountains and speed restrictions of tighter curves and bending\curving the track 90 degrees seems to be too big\long. Perhaps I am not doing something right but it does not seem to be possible to raise or lower track to be the same level as the terrain, where terrain will be raised on tracks or cut through's will be created through terrain leaving the track level. When it comes to road vehicles I created a bus route with one horse carriage though a busy town but it just lost money and did not make anything - perhaps the early road vehicles just cant and only later in the game with more demand and bigger vehicles. The houses also look incredibly modern for the 1800's. The Music is partcularly good which many tracks having a guitar feel of The Shadows".

As a test
date: I also tried playing the game with an erection
recommended: but this made the game even less enjoyable.\n\nI don't think in its current form this game is worth £20. Its more like a £10 game at present."

reviewText:
Do NOT get this game until they get it right. They said this game was easy to build with. It’s far from it. This game feels like it’s still in Alpha. Things the Dev's need to address before I'd recommend this game.
An UNDO Button. I hate wasting my money when a road or Track doesn’t want to connect. Even with a money cheat this was a pain in the butt. Tracks not connecting where I want them to. I couldn’t make a decent train yard without laying Miles and Miles of track.
I'd like to see drag and drop adjustments when laying a track or road. Example: lay a stretch of track. And being able to move different parts of it before finalizing the track.
Tracks don’t like to merge (RxR) with any road that the PLAYER sets down. I tried leveling the ground, making  a tunnel, and even tried a bridge. Always got a collision error" or "unusable space"
date:
or even “Not enough space”.
A better tutorial. They show you how to get bus's running to get the people moving and how to lay a starting passenger train set up. But they don’t teach you how to get cargo moving or how to merge it to your trains.
A SELL Button in the bus depot. I hate having to make a route just to use the "return to depot and sell" button... Such a pain in the butt.
The Dev's really could take a lesson from Railroad Tycoon. This game has SO MUCH protenchel
recommended: I'd hate to see it fail.\n"

reviewText:
This game could be fun. Unfortunately it comes with no documentation. There is a small palette onscreen when you start a game that briefly outlines how to do the first two stops of a line. That is all.

When you combine that with the picky way the game wants you build road and track systems, you will find yourself struggling to connect lines and stations, because the game can't manage its own topography. It simply has no tolerence for any variation in terrain, curvature or elevation. Straight lines are a breeze- but connecting all those lines is a chore.

Don't even try complex interchanges on railoads until you've experimented for a while- for example, as I understand it you cannot at time of writing build a road across existing railroad tracks, at all. You can only build tracks over roads- otherwise you will have to bulldoze the track, connect your road and rebuild the railroad again. And every time you tear down a section of road or track, you'll also have to use the leveling tool as well, because you won't be able to build anything other than what was already there until you flatten the terrain again. Because of this, I don't even bother with anything other than flat" terrain maps
date: as anything else is just asking for extra fiddling around.\n\nTo add insult to injury
recommended: as you pixel-hunt for the few places you can actually build on or join sections
hoursPlayed: the game likes to makes sound effects. So as you patiently wiggle the cursor around
voteText: hoping for that little green check mark
helpfulPercent: you've got a  little jackhammer noise rattling away everytime you move your cursor. rattle rattle rattle.\n\nYou can get the hang of it after a while
votesHelpful: but even then you'll be fiddling around. I just quit the game after I built a whole industrial complex of road-train cargo lines supporting the local indsutry - the wagons simply will not find a path. I have three stops and a depot
votesTotal: and not a single stop works with the pathfinding. The road itself is fine from what I can see. Gaaah.. I just couldn't be bothered any more. Every project involves massive setbacks as you discover you can't connect something with something else
votesFunny: becase the game gives you no guidance and no hint as to how much space the segments need. It's pure guesswork.\n\nOnce you manage to get everything working
commentsCount: it's fun to watch the trains. But there isn't a lot of depth here. You'll build train stations and depots and stops and plan lines until you're bored
column16: and then one day you'll do it again. or not. You can't control scheduling
column17: you can't set fares. One thing I find particularly annoying is that if you have a new line and buy new vehicles for it
column18: you can't just buy a fleet and set them on their route. If you do that the game will send every vehicle on the new line all at once. It doesn't make sense.\n\nThere are a few other issues as well. Performance could be much better (zooming causes heavy stuttering)
column19: the interface is unfinished (palette locations aren't saved
column20: so every time you open a game

column22: I've had several issues with road vehicle pathfinding at cargo stations- they can't tolerate more than two vehicles at a time it seems). Other minor quibbles but those are the main issues.\n\nIt's disappointing. Train Fever could be much better- it might even already be - but I can't tell
