reviewText:
Very disappointed. Maybe I was expecting too much!  I prepurchased this after reading the early access reviews (though i was unable to gain early access! really must follow kickstarter more often).  And watching the teaser videos.  It looked so good! like Railroad Tycoon but, better.

Sorry, but it is not.  It is not even close to as enjoyable as RT3 is, it is, depressing.

So here is a run down of what I worked on in the game.  Started with a small map, medium terrain and easy.  (as advised)

I followed the tutorial to make a bus route in the larger town on the map.   Started making revenue.   Went off and watched 5 episodes of Breaking Bad as my wife wanted to revist the show.  Went to bed.   Woke next morning made 10 million!!!! Game finshed then.   Pretty much.

Thought about and started to make a transport route to take  in some of that tasty commerce travellng (by foot) along the roads.  Can't build a road on a track that is already there,  huh,  Ok, building one alongsides is pointless and incredibly hard.  Flood the road with trucks after several infuriating attempts to set up a distribution point.   30 trucks.  6 episodes of Breaking bad return to more money!  ok now the game is finished?  Nope I want to do what is plastered all over the front.  Build the best rail network the world has ever seen!  Nope.

Infuriatingly unintuitive railtrack laying system that seems to have a default route that will burn through your millions as it carves its way over under and through the landscape with little or no ability of the player to work around obsticles.  Crossing rivers? yeah, maybe if the game allows it at that point,  have a selecton of bridges to choose from, only allowed to select the one the game lets you select.

Oh, and when you have built this track and laid out the right stations you have to spend a fortune maintaining the track and trains and the roods vehicles that deteriate over time sucking more of your hard earned money.

So I restart.  I have the best bus/tram route the world has ever seen!  I make Buckets of money every year!  I have no debt! I have no railway or commerce trucks.

I am so happy i unistalled the game.  Maybe after a year the game will have been worked on and finished, because it certainly isn't at this finished at this point.  Or, maybe the developers will bring out Train Feaver 2 for another $35 and it will have fixed all that was wrong in the first game.

I wanted to be happy with it, I really did.

reviewText:
I consider this being in alpha stage with very limited features and UI. Graphics are great, but that's all. With that much limited options, one cannot even think of comparing this game to openTTD, not even the orignal TTD.

I haven't played much since the game is constantly crashing. At this point, I am very disappointed - I hope the devs are planning to improve the game.

EDIT: A patch (the third probably) made the game playable for me. However, it just deepened my disappointment: when you finally grasp (or read somewhere on the net) how the cargo is actually moved around, it is a pain to construct anything more complicated. The construction tool is hard to use but you can manage to build something (although no crossings are allowed...) All the fun stops when you get something like I can't find a way to my stop" from a train that was built in a depot just next to the line and has direct access to it. Pathfinding is a chapter for itslelf... There are still some other bugs like the trucks on distincts lines blocking each other at stations
date: which renders these stations useless for multiple lines. And more and more... so the feeling that the devs should charge for a full release is still around...:-(\n\nEDIT: build 6219. The devs are definitely working on the game - the performance is now much better. The UI is also somewhat improved
recommended: but there are still glitches like windows constantly opening out of view. Second sad thing is that your trucks can still get easily blocked: 4 lines at connected to a 4 platform large truck station often end up with 2 lines using the same platform (not a hard algorithm to get that right
hoursPlayed: hm?). You can try to remove stations so the linkink resets...which might help you until next change. But you usually get stuck again as the old linking is stil used for incoming trucks...\n\nOn the other hand
voteText: some updates are cool

reviewText:
I was so eager to play this game and I was disappointed even more.
Train Fever must be naturally compared with Transport Tycon and OTTD, and it is so far away of playability and complexcity of those games. I like graphics and sounds, it is good enough for this type of game. I was also surprised by a music, but I was kind of anoying after 90 minutes of playing.
Building of tracks is awesome and annoying together. I love a possibility of a free building as it seems like a real track, but it is hard to guess which track is buildable, so it is needed to build & destroy back and forth to continue construction of the track from one city to another. A planing mode would be a nice feature. I wasn't also able to find any shortcuts for building, but may be I was just not looking enough.
I am probably too much used to build complex traffic light chains in OTTD, but a traffic control in this game is a huge step back.

The game also crashed 3 times while I played it for not even 2 hrs and there is no option to reload a recent state, so I give up

One day it might be a good game, which is fun to play, but now I regret at spending 23EUR. It is not worth it.

reviewText:
Not as good as I expected. I've played several versions of Railroad Tycoon, along with SimCity and other transportation and urban simulations, and while this one is pretty and has some enticing features, the overall game play is frustrating.

Some positives: It is nice being able to manage transportation within cities and between them. The ability to use buses and trams and not just trains is fun. Detailed reports of how each line and vehicle is doing are nice. The visuals are good.

Some negatives: Overall game play is just plain frustrating. In a game like this, the main experience is in setting up routes and connecting things. This game basically ruins this experience.

It's not so bad when setting up bus lines, since you are using existing roads, but it totally fails when you start laying railroads. It is almost impossible to get a railroad to cross a road. This appears to be related to grade differences, because typically the tracks are running in a cut or embankment that is above or below the road grade. Why can't the AI just automatically regrade the road so that the two can cross, and add to the railroad cost accordingly. The last thing I want to do is have to fiddle with individually grading road crossings, especially since it is expensive and time consuming and may fail, since even after I'm done, I won't be able to know if the tracks can go there anyway.

Industries are a major pain. You are supposed to build a depot next to the industry, and it may or may not begin to fill with some of the goods that otherwise magically travel down the road by other means. After building expensive depots at two industries that should feed into each other and the tracks to connect them, it typcially happens that you watch the goods totally ignore your nice transportation system and continue marching down the road without your assistance. Maybe there is a reason for this--some parameter that needs to be set, some limit on the placement of the depot. But if there is, it is a complete mystery, since there is no documentation that would help you figure it out.

Speaking of documentation, this game really lacks it. There is a very basic tutorial at the start, but nothing for the more advanced things you typically would like to try.

The game largely feels unfinished and untested, and not worth the rather high price that would be more appropriate for a game that totally works.

I love transportation sims, and I laid down a fairly large chunk of cash to buy this. But I'm not playing it. Life is frustrating enough without having a game make it worse.

reviewText:
19 minutes in, already gave up.

- The interface is terrible. No zoom to cursor. Can't scroll on the screen edges that have menus. This includes all corners, so you can't scoll diagonally.
- The cargo system is unrealistic. For example, you have to build truck depots near industries. One of the main advantages of trucks in real life is that they don't require depots or yards - trucks just go from industry dock to industry dock.
- There is no good way to visualize the cargo economy. In railroad tycoon, you could switch to a cargo view, which would show you where a good was produced and demanded. In this game, you just have to hunt around until you happen upon two industries that will create a supply chain.
- Optimization is abysmal or non-existent. This game is incredibly sluggish, and I have a fairly powerful rig.

Looks like it's back to Railroad Tycoon 3 for me.

reviewText:
Train Fever is a sandbox transport company management game with as many good ideas as flaws, making the experience rather jarring and not entirely recommendable, and certainly not at full price.

The main flaws concern the mechanics and the ergonomics of the game. While people often say that such and such game don’t hold your hand, I never felt it truer than in Train Fever. Although prepared, even before purchase, I still had to look up quite a lot of information elsewhere, but this is fun to me, understanding the inner workings and mechanics at play. Sadly, even now it seems to me that some mechanics are still not understood, or at least not fully, making it rather difficult to reach an optimal play style.

But the flaws become even more apparent on a higher difficulty level. While the game is perhaps too easy on lower settings, on hard mode the lower profit margins and the limitations of the construction tool require a near perfect play style. It is just plain unfair: cargo is profitable, but not passenger transport. You would think that a vehicle full of people would make a profit, no matter what, and I’m not talking just about trains here, where you could argue that you need more wagons to transport more people and thus improve the profit margins (which doesn’t work by the way: there is a limit to how much a locomotive can pull, and that’s even disregarding the artificial transportation time limit of twenty minutes the game forces upon you). It might have something to do with the travel distance, which gives a bonus to the income of each line, but since it is rather difficult to measure distances (only travel time), it’s hard to judge what line will or will not turn up a profit without testing first, which is not an option with the limited resources of a higher difficulty level. And even then, it doesn’t explain why cargo is always profitable, regardless of travel time or distance.

Still, you need both cargo and passenger to improve your cities (and even about that I’m not sure since nothing is explained and there doesn’t seem to be a consensus on the forums about it. Some say its cargo, other passengers, others still argue it is both. I’ve heard it say that’s it’s actually the line usage percentage that is used in city growth but from my experience that wasn’t the case, with cities with lower index actually growing while interconnected ones didn’t budge at all, even over longer periods of time). It would thus seem that people and goods are a must to make a profit later on: as you progress in the game, the running costs of vehicles rise, which means that more passengers or goods are required to make a profit. It is thus my belief that you can screw yourself completely over in this game if you take too slow a start, and don’t develop the cities rapidly.
It feels completely unbalanced, with the effect of the player feeling rather limited or the sensation that it comes down to luck. It’s hard to get involved when your impact on the game world feels so loose sometimes.

What actually makes the whole ordeal truly worse is the interface. Replacing vehicle is horribly unintuitive and slow, with the game opening dozens of tabs at a time, grinding the game (already in need of performance optimisation) to a halt, regardless of the characteristics of your computer.
The construction tool isn’t much better. The way double lanes work isn’t intuitive at all, but it is manageable. Problems arise when trying to get double tracks crossed by other double tracks and so forth, although the difficulty might come from the fidgetiness of the construction tools. It’s not completely broken, and that’s what makes it so aggravating to me. If it was completely broken, I would just stop playing, but since there is always a way to do what I wanted, with a lot of work and patience, I tried.

On a final side note, it should be said that the music is fantastic, I did truly enjoy it. Weirdly enough, it somehow felt like it made perfect sense in this game.

Still, the value of the game is to hold ones attention for long hours without pause. There is always something to do, always something to improve, to update, new routes to plan, etc. That, to me, is fun, and truly addicting. It’s one of those management games where time just flies by, something that I haven’t experience since my time with the Anno series. It’s just a shame it had to come with so many faults. I grew tired of having to put up with them and just stopped playing after that, feeling disappointed.

reviewText: I found this game very hard to play. Not because of difficulty, but because of game mechanics and functionality. My first issue is that when I switch to 1920x1080 I have an issue where my mouse won't be able to move into 1/3 of the screen anymore. My biggest issue with this is that the settings option is on the 1/3 of the screen that I can not use and after uninstalling and reinstalling the game I am still experiencing the issue. The second issue that I am having is that the track placement is very clunky. I will try to lay down some track between two stations and it will usually tell me that there is a terrain issue. Or I will try to place some track and the price of the track will jump dramatically because it is going to automatically adjust some terrain or build a bridge. So I often find myself spending a lot of time placing track inch by inch to make sure that the game will not overcharge me and bankrupt me. The third major issue I am having is that I cannot seem to get some road objects to make a propper line and thus I can't use one of the expensive stations I just put down and have to leave it there or bulldoze it for a price. This game feels like it should still be under development.\n\ntl:dr Game has weird glitches and frustrating mechanics.

reviewText:
This game unfortunately feels unfinished and unpolished. It has several issues besides the known problems that with some system configurations  the game often crashes or is completely unplayable. Following the issues I came across and that I feel need to be adressed soon.

First off the track laying. One of the most important parts of a game like this is the track laying. However it often is just not working properly. For example on a pefectly flat peace of land the game desides that the track after you crossed a street has to go up and starts building a ramp for no reason. This happens often and leads to the player fiddling around to correct the issue.

Another issue is the performance. I do have a good middle class PC where games like X-Rebirth, Guild Wars 2 and Sim City 5 can be perfectly played on almost maximum settings. But with this game even on a small map with medium settings the game often starts to stutter and the mouse lags like hell. This might not sound like a big deal but in fact it is because everyone who does not have an absolute high end gaming rig will not be able to enjoy maps bigger than ones who can accomodate at maximum 4 to 6 bigger towns!

Just not to my taste is that you have to start out at a time where horse carriages are the only street cars available. I want to be able to set the start date from the beginning on by myself and as I please. As of now you have to achieve certain goals to open up the options to start at another date.

If they fix these issues the game might become enjoyable.

reviewText:
Played 30 minutes, managed to finish the tutorial but couldn't figure out much else. The last 15 minutes were spent trying to figure out how to delete a train, and how to make it go back to de depot apparently after I added a second train everything ground to a halt and I had no idea how to fix it. Tutorial is extremely short and leaves crucial stuff out.

The UI is barely better than classic Transport Tycoon which is 20 yo by now: windows pop under or over others, stuff you need is spread confusingly between multiple tabs. Appears designed for 640x480 screens. Music sounds like elevator music. Can't zoom the map out all the way. Graphics look dated, RRT3 looked way better and it's a 10 year old game.

All that stuff is forgivable but it looks like micromanagement hell and that breaks it for me. Was expecting it to be Railroad Tycoon 3 but better, it isn't, it's TTD with a prettier UI and I hated TTD because of all the micro. Probably won't launch the game again. Pretty sad tbh.

reviewText:
I have tried it a bit further today, and after the advice given, it is a bit clearer now. I have an idea how to make money now and I can get my emperium off the ground.

However, understanding the basic concept now shows that the game is rather dull and empty. After a few bus lines and a single train line(which makes some good money, by the way) I have found that it is mostly waiting to get enough dough to continue on. Outside of buying a few vehicles and laying out the lines, there is nothing to do in between.

Oh, and removing a depot renders your vehicles to that depot useless, you can't send them back anymore or send them back to your depot because it can't find one, even though I already had build one on almost the exact same place, on the exact same road.

The UI is vague, the mouse moves like crap for some reason and the FPS isn't too good either. The music is absolutely abysmal and made me want to quit this game before it's even started. Oh, and when you save manually you cannot overwrite your current one(apparently)

I should have known, because every single one of these games end up the same, but the screenshots looked so great.

While my view on it is better than it was earlier, I still do not think it is worth the 25euros/dollars/regional equivalent you pay for it. I really do hope the developers continue to develop it, because it really needs it.

--Updated the review after some advice from McLOVIN

reviewText:
Sadly this game is let down by a clunky user experience without refinement.

Please can you make it easier to replace a 16 year old wagon ( or other item) on the same line.  Why can this not be done with a single click from the old wagons information page?  Instead you have to remember which wagon is old and on what line.. scrap it then buy a new one.... the put it back onto the original line..... not really user friendly.

Saving a game is equally as bad....  it does not show up game history or previous files ....  Whilst on this subject the auto save pauses the game.... a real irritation when already frustrated

Come on  - I know the game starts in the 1800's but the user interface should not be that antiquated.  Get some user testing and feedback done please and streamline the whole experience.

This should be a great game, alongside any of the major Sims.... but it needs a lot of tweaking and streamlining before I play it again, Sorry.

reviewText: I have really, really tried to like this game but it is so annoying. No manual so just other players input. There are so many things you can't do, like put crossover tracks on a bridge, signals on a bridge, can't supply industry from more than one resource.....the list is endless. And you only discover this by trial and error and bulldozing or repeated reloading.\nIMHO procedures and routines have been botched to make things try and work. When building a railway and you have everything ready to go, click set line.....and the train has no path" even though the coloured "path" is lit. The problem is that you have the game paused. This is such lazy programming that is unexcusable. A simple "Paused" would be more appropriate
date: but you end up checking the line for faults for 15-20mins anyway.\nDepending how many vehicles you have on a line will determine your frequency. You may have a frequency of 3mins
hoursPlayed: they take 5 months to get there!  Also

two trains on the same track with the same number of passengers and yet they get different income!
With one train carrying upto 64 passengers why do so many disappear? Poor programming again!
The game is only half finished judging by all the updates that are being implemented and due.
My i5 4570 is o/c to 4.2Ghz and my HD 7850 is o/c 20% and on a large map with large cities and everything turned low

reviewText:
41 Minutes into the game, and I have absolutely no clue how to play it. I managed to place a couple bus stations and spent the next 15-20 minutes figuring out how the hell I am supposed to buy a vehicle. Once I finally figured that out, I tried placing a Railroad and let me tell ya, it is very hard and very expensive to place track. I still haven't even gotten as far as buying a train because I cannot get the track layed out.

I am very frustrated mainly because the tutorial is so basic that you are struggling to figure out how the hell your supposed to lay your roads and track and even transport things, let alone make money doing it.

I am only 41 minutes into gameplay and I already regret spending an outrageous $35. This review is posted on Dec. 15 2014. I will attempt to play it again when I call down from buyers remorse.

I wouldn't recommend buying this game if you are depending on a tutorial to teach you. Frustration sets in quickly, so if you have no patience, do not buy this game.

reviewText:
Oh my...
This is what happens when you offer wannabe-developers an unchecked realm to dump their trash upon the public. I don't even understand how Total Biscuit was able to take more than 10 minutes of it. (In fact he even excused the lacking options-screen, so he probably has a stake in this title, I guess.)

Basicaly what we have here is a transport-tycoon offering that misses the mark on everything it touches.
-Management is obtuse, confusing and totally left to the player to figure out.
-It's called trainfever, but trains will bankrupt you.
-Randomly generated map that actually blocks you from doing what you want.
-Incredibly slow. So damn slow... So slooow... (Kill me now.)
-Trucks and buses are where it's at. Ignore trams and trains or go bankrupt.
-Most poorly optimized game of this decade. It must be a new standard for developers, I think.
-Simulation depth is threadbare, uninteresting and not at all offering an incentive to play.
-Industry can be ignored.
-Trams and train can be ignored.
-Developing cities can be ignored.
-Upgrading roads can be ignored.
-Modernizing your fleet is agonizing punishment.
-Music is worse than elevator muzak.

I wish this developer saved himself and us the trouble. I think that this developer hates gamers and especially those gamers that like transport-tycoon style games. I have no other handle on Train Fever to explain it's sorry existence. There can be no other explanation. This developer actively hates you and tries to have you commit suicide while you slowly come to realise, as you play Train Fever, that you're a pathetic slug who shouldn't be alive.

Prove him wrong! Don't buy this contender for Ultimate Trash Cash Grab 2014.

reviewText:
After some time the game has come so far. better performance , so many mods and so on ;) therefore i change my review to positive



___________________________________
Nice concept BUT:

- massive performance issues (stuttering, even on very low settings, guess coding sucks ♥♥♥)
- only 4 chains of industrie, a total joke compared to games loke transport tycoon (which, says the devs, inspired them)
- to few options to switch icons on and off
- no minimap, so finding your stuff is annoyingly frustrating onl arger maps
- to few options to show values like how steep your track is etc
- to few cars/trains .... it s a span of 150 years and you have like a dozen different trains or buses lol :(

The only nice thins is it s good looking, but it lacks the depth.... it s just a casual game for me :( . The idea was great, but that's it it WAS great but the way the devs brought it to the computer is ...let's say below average.

Edit 05.09.2014
The mechanic of not upgradinga trainstation is totally ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. all the time you get collision error or smt and you cannot build it at the same spot again, waht dev is so stupid to to such things, or are the devs to stupid to programm such stuff? i just had a game where i was still in the early years and wanted to have 2 tracks at a station buuut after deleting the first one and wanting to put the same station just with 2 tracks at the same sport the game says uhh you cannot smt is in the way....wtf ? your kidding me...now no money left and alt + f4 this game is done for me. delte and be sad the money is gone :(

Edit:
I gave it up. The massive stuttering is the worst. Every time you try to build Bus stops or smt else the fps drop like mad from 60 to 10 this is clearly a game issue. Nothing to do with my specs and so on, cause when i don't touch anything just watch the game fps are between 30 to 60 (depends on the angle i watch the landscape) but when i try to do smt with the game tools ( building and stuff) fps go down. This leads to deinstall of this game. But sadly this ins a game breaking bug !

reviewText: Great game! The train lines are a challenge and even after I think I've got them down pat, they sometimes still do things I'm not so sure are right, or at least, don't make sense to me. But that's part of what makes this game one you can play for a really long time. Even after you acheive certain goals and make millions, you can still work the game with several different objectives. I thought I might get tired of it after reaching the year 2000 but I have gone back and started new maps and tried to succeed different ways. It's been tough and I like that!\nThe graphics are enjoyable and that's something I'm kind of picky about in games. The best thing about this game that I like is that you're not just building train lines, you're creating the towns with transport lines as well. I haven't even gotten into some of the mods yet, which I'm looking forward to. I'm still satisfied playing the base game for now, more like savoring it. But I think I saw a mod with plopable buildings which really excites me!

reviewText: Been playing this for a while now and have been delighted with it. Really enjoying the gameplay, the graphics are great and I have had no lag on my (low average) PC. I simply don't understand why this game has not been a smash hit with some users. I'm genuinely baffled. Ah, well - we can't all like the same thing I suppose.\n\nI've even managed to edit a couple of files so that my towns are now all named after towns in my local area. The game has run well with no crashes at all. I really look forward to continuing my game each day. So relaxing and a pleasure to play. I don't usually write game reviews but I felt this game deserves a bit of praise. So that's my verdict - great!

reviewText:
Very steep learning curve. Watch a few videos on YouTube if you get frustrated. Fun game though, especially if you get it on sale. Not worth $20, but anything under that it's a good buy.
Some things I've learned: You don't need to add a bus line or tram line to a city before you connect passenger rail.
Passenger rail is the most lucrative thing you can do (That I've found) - start early with one good line on flat land and you'll do well.
Be very catutious before investing a lot of money in cargo lines, so far they've been money pits in 9/10 situations. Even when the cargo is really flowing I haven't had a lot of luck generating a lot of profit from it.
Signals are unecessairly complicated but once you get it it makes sense.
Have fun!

If you want a virtual model-railway which you can build and feels alive, then this is a good buy.
Its not about driving trains but see them ride.
You need to practice some with track laying, but once you have the hang of it you can build nice layouts.
And then there is the nice mod community (actualy 2, a German and a Russian one) with tons of mods for vehicles, objects (which are free placeable since the last update) and game changing mods.

reviewText: This is a fun game, with pros and cons. Adequate management in various forms of transport, from over the road to railroad. Trains do some pretty stupid things once in a while, like sit face-to-face at a signal for no apparent reason. There is no warning for when trains have stopped, or are becoming excessively late for their routes. The game has no intermittent signals like in real life. This allows trains to follow closer than switches as long as they are Goin the same direction. Need excessive amounts of double iron to handle some train traffic in the case to track overload. A few updates, and addition of a few features that are used on railroads in real life would make game a lot more enjoyable. Still very fun, definitely recommend.
